revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/202.51.69.4|202.51.69.4]] ([[User talk:202.51.69.4|talk]]) to last revision by Smasongarrison. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} [[File:Aamir Khan 2013.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1|Khan at an event for ''[[Dhoom 3]]'' in 2013, which ranks among the five films starring Khan that have held the record for being the [[List of highest-grossing Indian films|highest-grossing Indian films]].]] [[Aamir Khan]] is an Indian actor, [[film producer|producer]], [[film director|director]] and [[television personality]]. Khan first appeared on screen at the age of eight in a minor role in his uncle [[Nasir Hussain]]'s film ''[[Yaadon Ki Baaraat]]'' (1973).{{cite web|last=Dedhia |first=Sonal |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-most-ambitious-project-of-aamirs-career/20120314.htm#4 |title=The Most Ambitious Project of Aamir's Career |publisher=[[Rediff.com]] |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=14 March 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317063506/http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-most-ambitious-project-of-aamirs-career/20120314.htm |archivedate=17 March 2012 |df= }} In 1983, he acted in and worked as an assistant director on ''Paranoia'', a short film directed by [[Aditya Bhattacharya]],{{cite news|last=Bamzai |first=Kaveree |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Aamir+Khan:+Mr+Blockbuster/1/78177.html |title=Aamir Khan: Mr Blockbuster |work=[[India Today]] |date=7 January 2010 |accessdate=20 February 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226214707/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Aamir%2BKhan%3A%2BMr%2BBlockbuster/1/78177.html |archivedate=26 February 2014 |df= }} following which he assisted Hussain on two of his directorial ventures{{mdash}}''[[Manzil Manzil]]'' (1984) and ''[[Zabardast]]'' (1985).{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/Aamir-Khan-to-return-to-direction/articleshow/17347135.cms?referral=PM |title=Aamir Khan to return to direction |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=25 November 2012 |accessdate=20 February 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220103330/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/Aamir-Khan-to-return-to-direction/articleshow/17347135.cms?referral=PM |archivedate=20 February 2014 |df= }} As an adult, Khan's first acting project was a brief role in the 1984 [[experimental film|experimental]] social drama ''[[Holi (1984 film)|Holi]]''.{{cite web|last=Verma |first=Sukanya |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-aamir-khans-top-25-movie-moments/20121128.htm#1 |title=Aamir Khan's 25 finest movie moments |publisher=Rediff.com |accessdate=26 January 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121201144530/http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-aamir-khans-top-25-movie-moments/20121128.htm |archivedate= 1 December 2012 |df= }} Khan's first leading role came opposite [[Juhi Chawla]] in the highly successful tragic romance ''[[Qayamat Se Qayamat Tak]]'' (1988).{{cite web|last=Vijaykar |first=Rajeev |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/features/type/view/id/3569/ |title=Qayamat Se Qayamat Tak: Turning-point |publisher=[[Bollywood Hungama]] |date=18 June 2012 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227181023/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/features/type/view/id/3569/ |archivedate=27 February 2014 |df= }} His performance in the film and in the thriller ''[[Raakh]]'' (1989) earned him a [[National Film Award – Special Mention (Feature Film)|National Film Award – Special Mention]].{{cite web|url=http://dff.nic.in/2011/36th_nff_1989.pdf |title=36th National Film Festival (1989) |publisher=[[Directorate of Film Festivals]] |accessdate=30 July 2011 |page=72 |format=PDF |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004082719/http://dff.nic.in/2011/36th_nff_1989.pdf |archivedate= 4 October 2011 |df= }} He went on to establish himself with roles in several lucrative films of the 1990s, including the romantic drama ''[[Dil (1990 film)|Dil]]'' (1990), the comedy-drama ''[[Hum Hain Rahi Pyar Ke]]'' (1993), and the {{INR}}871 million (about {{USD|24.5 million}} in 1996){{ref|1|[I]}}-grossing romance ''[[Raja Hindustani]]'' (1996).{{cite web|title=Top Lifetime Grossers Worldwide |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=312&catName=TGlmZXRpbWU= |publisher=[[Box Office India]] |accessdate=9 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015223626/http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=312&catName=TGlmZXRpbWU%3D |archivedate=15 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite book|title=India Book of the Year |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-9tAAAAMAAJ |year=2003 |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica (India) Pvt. Ltd. |page=125 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140704042629/http://books.google.com/books?id=D-9tAAAAMAAJ |archivedate= 4 July 2014 |df= }} He also played against [[typecasting (acting)|type]] in the [[Deepa Mehta]]-directed [[Cinema of Canada|Canadian]]-Indian co-production ''[[Earth (1998 film)|Earth]]'' (1998).{{cite web|last=Chaudhary |first=Alpana |url=http://www.rediff.com/entertai/1998/jun/03am.htm |title=Of Earth and a star |publisher=Rediff.com |date=3 June 1998 |accessdate=26 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104221837/http://www.rediff.com/entertai/1998/jun/03am.htm |archivedate= 4 November 2012 |df= }} In 1999, Khan launched a production company, [[Aamir Khan Productions]],{{cite book|last=Punathambekar |first=Aswin |title=From Bombay to Bollywood: The Making of a Global Media Industry |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4bclkJ3V7XYC&pg=PA191 |date=24 July 2013 |publisher=NYU Press |isbn=978-0-8147-2948-9 |page=191 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140704121822/http://books.google.com/books?id=4bclkJ3V7XYC&pg=PA191 |archivedate= 4 July 2014 |df= }} whose first release ''[[Lagaan]]'' (2001) was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]],{{cite book|last=Ebert |first=Roger |title=Roger Ebert's Movie Yearbook 2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2V34EMJkaAIC&pg=PA364 |year=2004 |publisher=Andrews McMeel Publishing |isbn=978-0-7407-4742-7 |pages=364–365 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140704121827/http://books.google.com/books?id=2V34EMJkaAIC&pg=PA364 |archivedate= 4 July 2014 |df= }} and earned him the [[National Film Award for Best Popular Film Providing Wholesome Entertainment|National Film Award for Best Popular Film]].{{cite news |title=South takes the lion's share; ''Lagaan'' wins 8 national awards |url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2002/07/27/stories/2002072702950100.htm |date=27 July 2002 |accessdate=13 January 2008 |work=[[The Hindu]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080116041648/http://www.hinduonnet.com/2002/07/27/stories/2002072702950100.htm |archivedate=16 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://filmfareawards.indiatimes.com/articleshow/articleshow/articleshow/368739.cms |title=The Winners{{mdash}}2001 |accessdate=4 April 2014 |publisher=Indiatimes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091130171946/http://filmfareawards.indiatimes.com/articleshow/articleshow/articleshow/368739.cms |archivedate=30 November 2009 |df= }} Also in 2001, he starred alongside [[Saif Ali Khan]] and [[Akshaye Khanna]] in the acclaimed drama ''[[Dil Chahta Hai]]''.{{cite book | title=I'll Do It My Way: The Incredible Journey of Aamir Khan| publisher=Om Books International | author=Daniels, Christina | year=2012 | pages=117–118 | isbn=978-93-80069-22-7}} ''Lagaan'' and ''Dil Chahta Hai'' are cited in the media as defining films of Hindi cinema.{{cite book|last=Varia |first=Kush |title=Bollywood: Gods, Glamour, and Gossip |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cmisAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA26 |date=25 December 2012 |publisher=Wallflower |isbn=978-1-906660-15-4 |pages=26–27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140704121714/http://books.google.com/books?id=cmisAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA26 |archivedate= 4 July 2014 |df= }}{{cite news |url= http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/thscrip/print.pl?file=2011062552310200.htm&date=2011/06/25/&prd=mp&|title= The Ascendance of Aamir |author= Rangan, Baradwaj|date= 25 July 2011|work= The Hindu|accessdate=26 January 2014}} After a four-year hiatus, Khan portrayed the [[Mangal Pandey|eponymous lead]] in ''[[Mangal Pandey: The Rising]]'' (2005), a period film that underperformed at the box office,{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/fr/2005/07/29/stories/2005072903210100.htm |title=Rising with a patriotic cry |author=Pillai, Sreedhar |date=29 July 2005 |work=The Hindu |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080601041210/http://www.hindu.com/fr/2005/07/29/stories/2005072903210100.htm |archivedate= 1 June 2008 |df= }} after which he played leading roles in two top-grossing films of 2006{{mdash}}''[[Fanaa (film)|Fanaa]]'' and ''[[Rang De Basanti]]''.{{cite web|publisher=Box Office India |title=Box Office 2006 |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=212&catName=MjAwNg== |accessdate=8 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014132118/http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=212&catName=MjAwNg%3D%3D |archivedate=14 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Khan made his directorial debut with ''[[Taare Zameen Par]]'' in 2007, a drama on [[dyslexia]] starring [[Darsheel Safary]], in which Khan also played a supporting role.{{cite web |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/features/2007/05/21/2665/index.html |title="Yes, I have directed Taare Zameen Par" – Aamir Khan |accessdate= 11 April 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728040211/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/features/2007/05/21/2665/index.html |archivedate= 28 July 2010 |last=Singh |first=Harneet |date=21 May 2007 |publisher=Bollywood Hungama}} The film proved to be a critical and commercial success, winning him the [[National Film Award for Best Film on Family Welfare]].{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/archieve/others/2009/sep/r2009090707.pdf |format=PDF |title=55th National Film Awards for the Year 2007 |publisher=Directorate of Film Festivals |page=3 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007125534/http://pib.nic.in/archieve/others/2009/sep/r2009090707.pdf |archivedate= 7 October 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://in.movies.yahoo.com/news-detail/20159/Taare-Zameen-Par-sweeps-Filmfare-Awards.html |title=Taare Zameen Par sweeps Filmfare Awards |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |date=24 February 2008 |accessdate=29 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rafxKY4f?url=http://in.movies.yahoo.com/news-detail/20159/Taare-Zameen-Par-sweeps-Filmfare-Awards.html |archivedate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Khan played a man suffering from [[anterograde amnesia]] in the 2008 thriller ''[[Ghajini (2008 film)|Ghajini]]'',{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080706/jsp/7days/story_9510393.jsp |title=In the black hole of the mind |work=[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]] |author=Jayan, T.V. |accessdate=16 April 2014 |date=6 July 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416181740/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080706/jsp/7days/story_9510393.jsp |archivedate=16 April 2014 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-01-12/india/28035919_1_ghajini-akshay-kumar-highest-grosser|title=Box Office: With Rs 200cr in kitty, 'Ghajini' rewrites records|work=The Times of India|author=Kazmi, Nikhat|accessdate=12 January 2009|date=12 January 2009}} after which he portrayed an engineering student in the comedy-drama ''[[3 Idiots]]'' (2009),{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5979&nCat=|title=Chennai Express Crosses Ek Tha Tiger Worldwide In Ten Days|publisher=Box Office India|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=19 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105220137/http://boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5979&nCat=|archivedate=5 November 2013 }} and a reclusive artist in the drama ''[[Dhobi Ghat (film)|Dhobi Ghat]]'' (2010), which he also produced.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/dhobi-ghat-to-hit-theatres-in-germany/article1-663856.aspx |title=Dhobi Ghat to hit theatres in Germany |date=18 February 2011 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407094309/http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/dhobi-ghat-to-hit-theatres-in-germany/article1-663856.aspx |archivedate= 7 April 2014 |df= }} Further success came when he played the antagonist of the adventure film ''[[Dhoom 3]]'' (2013) and starred as the titular alien in the {{INRConvert|7.4|b}}-grossing satire ''[[PK (film)|PK]]'' (2014).{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6355&nCat|title=Dhoom 3 ALL TIME Number One Worldwide Grosser: 500 cr Plus Expected|publisher=Box Office India|accessdate=13 January 2014|date=1 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102192306/http://boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6355&nCat|archivedate=2 January 2014 }}{{cite news|last=Chatterjee |first=Saibal |title=PK Movie Review |url=http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/pk-movie-reviz1068 |publisher=NDTV |date=19 December 2014 |accessdate=20 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220124245/http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/pk-movie-reviz1068 |archivedate=20 December 2014 |df= }}{{cite web|title=PK Hits 700 Crore Worldwide - China At 14.5 Million |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/Details/art_detail/pkhits700croreworldwidechinaat145million |publisher=Box Office India |date=6 June 2015 |accessdate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150608160137/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/Details/art_detail/pkhits700croreworldwidechinaat145million |archivedate= 8 June 2015 |df= }} In 2016, Khan played the father of two young female wrestlers in the sports biopic ''[[Dangal (film)|Dangal]]'', which earned over {{INRConvert|20|b}} worldwide.{{cite web |title=Dangal v Bahubali 2 Worldwide Update |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/report-details.php?articleid=2971 |publisher=Box Office India |date=1 June 2017 |accessdate=2 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603203816/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/report-details.php?articleid=2971 |archivedate=3 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Five of Khan's films{{mdash}}''Ghajini'', ''3 Idiots'', ''Dhoom 3'', ''PK'', and ''Dangal''{{mdash}} have held records for being the [[List of highest-grossing Indian films|highest-grossing Indian film of all time]].{{cite news|last=Hoad |first=Phil |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jan/07/global-box-office-pk-the-hobbit-big-hero-6-unbroken |title=Aamir Khan's religious satire PK becomes India's most successful film |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=7 January 2015 |accessdate=8 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107183230/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jan/07/global-box-office-pk-the-hobbit-big-hero-6-unbroken |archivedate= 7 January 2015 |df= }} In addition to acting in films, Khan has developed and featured as the host of the television talk show ''[[Satyamev Jayate (TV series)|Satyamev Jayate]]'' (2012–14).{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-jittery-when-i-signed-up-for-tv-aamir-khan-1675420 |title=Jittery when I signed up for TV: Aamir Khan |date=13 April 2012 |accessdate=2 April 2014 |newspaper=[[Daily News and Analysis]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407091635/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-jittery-when-i-signed-up-for-tv-aamir-khan-1675420 |archivedate= 7 April 2014 |df= }} ==Films== {| news|last=Kapoor|first=Rajat|url=http://www.mansworldindia.com/cinema/the-mentor-and-the-student|title=The Mentor and the student|work=[[Man's World (magazine)|Man's World]]|date=26 April 2011|accessdate=20 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224005754/http://www.mansworldindia.com/cinema/the-mentor-and-the-student|archivedate=24 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}

{{cite web|title=Dil (1990)|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/cast/id/201708|publisher=Bollywood Hungama|accessdate=4 April 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407094810/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/cast/id/201708|archivedate=7 April 2014|df=dmy-all}}
{{cite web|url=http://filmfareawards.indiatimes.com/articleshow/articleshow/368593.cms |title=The Nominations {{mdash}} 1990 |accessdate=9 May 2014 |publisher=Indiatimes.com }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |- ! scope="row" align="left" |''[[Deewana Mujh Sa Nahin]]'' || 1990|| {{yes}} || || || {{Sort|Sharma|Ajay Sharma}} |Y. {{Cite news|url=https://www.filmfare.com/features/nominations-for-the-63rd-jio-filmfare-awards-2018_-26161-21.html|title=Nominations for the 63rd Jio Filmfare Awards 2018|work=filmfare.com|access-date=2018-01-18|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119060626/https://www.filmfare.com/features/nominations-for-the-63rd-jio-filmfare-awards-2018_-26161-21.html|archivedate=19 January 2018|df=dmy-all}} |- ! scope="row" align="left"|''[[Thugs of Hindostan]]'' |2018|| {{yes}} || || ||Firangi |[[Vijay Krishna Acharya]]|| || style="text-align: center;" |{{cite web|title=Thugs of Hindostan: Katrina Kaif is our last thug, confirms Aamir Khan |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/katrina-kaif-aamir-khan-thugs-of-hindostan/1/951898.html |accessdate=13 May 2017 |publisher=India Today |date=12 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170512080127/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/katrina-kaif-aamir-khan-thugs-of-hindostan/1/951898.html |archivedate=12 May 2017|df=}} |} ==Television== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align: margin;" |- ! scope="col" style="width: 17em;" | Title ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" style="width: 12em;" | Role ! scope="col" style="width: 15em;" | Creator(s) ! scope="col" style="width: 15em;" class="unsortable"| Episode(s) ! scope="col" style="width: 2em;" class="unsortable" | Ref. |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Satyamev Jayate (TV series)|Satyamev Jayate]]'' | 2012–14 | Host | Himself | [[Satyamev Jayate (Season 1)|Season 1]], [[Satyamev Jayate (Season 2)|Season 2]] & [[Satyamev Jayate (Season 3)|Season 3]] | style="text-align: center;" | |- ! scope="row"| ''[[C.I.D. (Indian TV series)|C.I.D.]]'' | 2012 | {{Sort|Shekhawat|Surjan Singh Shekhawat}} | {{Sort|Singh|[[B. P. Singh]]}} | "Red Suitcase Murders" | style="text-align: center;" |{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/tv/news-interviews/Aamir-Khan-helps-the-CID-team-to-solve-a-case/articleshow/17322057.cms |title=Aamir Khan helps the CID team to solve a case |work=The Times of India |date=23 November 2012 |accessdate=20 February 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222103443/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/tv/news-interviews/Aamir-Khan-helps-the-CID-team-to-solve-a-case/articleshow/17322057.cms |archivedate=22 December 2015 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"| ''Toofan Alaya'' | 2017– | Guest | Himself | Season 1, Season 2 | style="text-align: center;" |{{cite web|url=https://www.deccanchronicle.com/entertainment/bollywood/230318/aamir-khan-marathi-toofan-alaya-tv-show-satyamev-jayate-paani-kiran.html|title=Toofan Alaya: Aamir Khan to feature in Marathi show for water conservation cause|publisher=''[[Deccan Chronicle]]''|date=23 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.loksatta.com/manoranjan-news/paani-foundation-water-cup-2017-tufaan-aalaya-promo-1446701/|title=‘पानी फाऊंडेशन’चा ‘तुफान आलंया..’ प्रोमो प्रदर्शित|publisher=''[[Loksatta]]''|date=5 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.india.com/buzz/aamir-khans-new-project-toofan-alaya-is-in-marathi-actor-tweets-trailer-watch-video-2000317/|title=Aamir Khan’s new project Toofan Alaya is in Marathi – actor tweets trailer! (Watch video)|publisher=''India.com''|date=6 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://aajtak.intoday.in/story/aamir-khan-shares-satyamev-jayate-water-cup-song-toofan-aala-1-905074.html|title='दंगल' के बाद आमिर खान लेकर आए हैं 'तूफान आला'|publisher=''[[Aaj Tak]]''|date=4 January 2017}} |} ==Music video appearances== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders unsortable" style="text-align: margin;" |- |- ! scope="col" style="width: 18em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width: 2em;"| Year ! scope="col" style="width: 10em;"| Performer(s) ! scope="col" style="width: 8em;"| Director(s) ! scope="col" style="width: 8em;"| Album ! scope="col" style="width: 2em;" | Ref. |- ! scope="row"| "Jab Bhi Chum Leta Hoon" | 2003 | [[Roop Kumar Rathod]] | Ashok Mehra | ''Pyar Ka Jashn'' | style="text-align: center;" |{{cite web|publisher=Rediff.com |last=Rana |first=Harini N. |title=Aamir's first music video |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2003/jun/16aamir.htm |date=16 June 2003 |accessdate=6 March 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407083720/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2003/jun/16aamir.htm |archivedate= 7 April 2014 |df= }} |} ==See also== * [[List of awards and nominations received by Aamir Khan|Awards and nominations received by Aamir Khan]] ==Footnotes== {{note|1|[I]}}The exchange rate in 1996 was 35.49 Indian rupees ({{INR}}) per 1 US dollar (US$).{{cite web|url=http://rbidocs.rbi.org.in/rdocs/Publications/PDFs/72784.pdf |title=Exchange Rate of the Indian Rupee Vis-a-Vis the SDR, US Dollar, Pound Sterling, D. M./Euro and Japanese Yen (Financial year — Annual average and end-year rates) |format=PDF |page=264 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417152231/http://rbidocs.rbi.org.in/rdocs/Publications/PDFs/72784.pdf |publisher=[[Reserve Bank of India]] |accessdate=17 April 2014 |archivedate=17 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}
{{note|2|[II]}}Khan played the younger version of [[Tariq Khan (actor)|Tariq Khan]]'s character in the film.
{{note|3|[III]}}Khan played the younger version of [[Mahendra Sandhu]]'s character in the film.
{{note|4|[IV]}}Khan played a character who portrays [[Chandrashekar Azad]] in a documentary featured in the film.{{cite news|last=Varma |first=Mishty |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/news-feed/nm21/a-case-for-rang-de-basanti-at-the-oscars/article1-199316.aspx |title=A case for Rang De Basanti at the Oscars |work=Hindustan Times |date=12 January 2007 |accessdate=4 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407100509/http://www.hindustantimes.com/news-feed/nm21/a-case-for-rang-de-basanti-at-the-oscars/article1-199316.aspx |archivedate= 7 April 2014 |df= }}
{{note|5|[V]}}Khan played a character who impersonates another man in the film.{{cite book|last1=Sen |first1=Meheli |last2=Basu |first2=Anustup |title=Figurations in Indian Film |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gadEAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA99 |date=21 October 2013 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=978-1-137-34978-1 |page=99 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140704122840/http://books.google.com/books?id=gadEAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA99 |archivedate= 4 July 2014 |df= }}
{{note|6|[VI]}}Khan performed dual roles in the film.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/i-like-samars-character-more-aamir-khan-on-his-dhoom-3-characters/443081-8-66.html |title=I like Samar's character more: Aamir Khan on his 'Dhoom 3' characters |publisher=CNN-IBN |date=3 January 2014 |accessdate=4 April 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407110051/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/i-like-samars-character-more-aamir-khan-on-his-dhoom-3-characters/443081-8-66.html |archivedate= 7 April 2014 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0451148|name=Aamir Khan}} * [http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/celebritymicro/index/id/60 Aamir Khan] on [[Bollywood Hungama]] {{Aamir Khan}} {{Portal bar|Bollywood|Film}} {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Aamir filmography}} [[Category:Aamir Khan]] [[Category:Indian filmographies]] [[Category:Actor filmographies]] [[Category:Director filmographies]]

{{Infobox person | name = Akk ibn Adnan | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = Founder of a Southern arabian tribe in [[Jordan]]. | spouse = A woman from the Asharites, a descendant of [[Qahtan]]. | children = Akk ibn al-Dith (father of Al-Shadid ibn Akk
[[Mudar|Sawda bint Akk]]) | parents = [[Adnan]]
Mahdad bint Laham ([[Jokshan|Banu Yaqshan]]) | relatives = [[Ma'ad ibn Adnan]] (brother) }} '''Al-Harith ibn Adnan''' ({{lang-ar|عك بن عدنان}}; perhaps the same as Akk) is the brother of [[Ma'ad ibn Adnan]], who is an ancestor of the [[Islamic prophet]] [[Muhammad]]. He is featured in ancient [[Arabic literature]]. ==Parentage== [[File:Adnanites.PNG|thumbnail|right|The Adnanite Arab family tree, created from "The Life of Mohammad" by [[Ibn Hisham]]]] Some say that [[Ma'ad ibn Adnan]] had a brother called Al-Dith, and that he was actually Akk. However, others say that Akk was the son of Al-Dith, and thus a grandson of [[Adnan]]. Nevertheless, the majority agree that Akk and Al-Dith are the same person, the son of [[Adnan]]. {{cite book |last=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari|al-Tabari]]|first=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari|Muhammad ibn Jarir]]|title=The History of al-Tabari Vol. 6: Muhammad at Mecca|page=36|year=1988|publisher=SUNY Press}} If Akk and Al-Dith are the same person, then his mother and the mother of [[Ma'ad ibn Adnan]] were the same. ==Tribe== Akk dwelt in the [[Qays and Yaman tribes|Yaman]] because he took a wife amongst the Asharites and lived with them, adopting their language. The Asharites were descended from [[Sabaeans|Saba']] ibn Yashjub ibn [[Yarab|Ya'rub]] ibn [[Qahtanites|Qahtan]]. {{cite book|last=[[Ibn Ishaq]]|first=[[Muhammad ibn Ishaq|Muhammad]]|title=The Life of Muhammad|page=4|publisher=Oxford University Press}} Akk was the founder of a Southern Arabian tribe, the tribe of Akk. According to the following verse, the mother of Madhij (the founder of another Southern tribe that settled in [[Jordan]]) was from Akk:
Woe to the mother of Madhij from Akk! (That is the mother of Madhij weeping) {{cite book |last=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari|al-Tabari]]|first=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari|Muhammad ibn Jarir]]|title=The History of al-Tabari Vol. 17: The First Civil War|page=46|year=1996|publisher=SUNY Press}}
Some genealogists say that Akk departed for Samran, in the [[Yemen]], leaving his brother [[Ma'ad]]. This is because, when the people of [[Hadur]] killed Shu'ayb b. Dhi Mahdam al- Haduri, [[God]] sent [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] against them as a punishment. [[Jeremiah|Armiya]] and Barkhiya went away taking [[Ma'ad]] with them, and when the warfare had died down they took him back to [[Mecca]]. [[Ma'ad]] then found that his brothers and uncles who were descended from Adnan had joined the [[Qays and Yaman tribes|peoples of the Yemen]] and had intermarried with them; the Yemenites had been sympathetic to them because they were descendants of [[Jurhum]]. They quote the following verse as proof of this story:
We left our brothers, al-Dith and Akk
on their way to Samran, and they departed quickly.
They were of the [[Adnanites|Banu Adnan]],
but they lost this descent irrevocably among themselves. {{cite book |last=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari|al-Tabari]]|first=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari|Muhammad ibn Jarir]]|title=The History of al-Tabari Vol. 6: Muhammad at Mecca|page=37|year=1988|publisher=SUNY Press}}
==See also== *[[Qahtan]] *[[Adnan]] *[[Ahl al-Bayt]] *[[Family tree of Muhammad]] *[[Family tree of Shaiba ibn Hashim]] *[[Banu Hashim]] *[[Quraysh (tribe)|Banu Quraysh]] *[[Banu Kinanah]] *[[Mudhar|Banu Mudhar]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Semitic-speaking peoples]] [[Category:Adnanites]] [[Category:Arabs]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Andreas Vollenweider | image = Andreas_Vollenweider.jpg | caption = | image_size = 260px | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|10|4|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Zürich]], [[Switzerland]] | years_active = 1975–present | genre = [[World music|World]], [[New-age music|new age]], [[Indian music|Indian]], [[Classical music|classical]], [[jazz fusion]] | occupation = Musician | label = [[Edel Records]]
Kin-Kou Music
Content Records
[[Sony Music Entertainment|CBS Records]]
[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]/[[Sony Music Entertainment|CBS Records]]
[[Sony Classical]]/[[Sony Music Entertainment|SME Records]]
[[SBK Records|SBK]]/[[EMI|EMI Records]] | website = http://www.vollenweider.com }} '''Andreas Vollenweider''' (born 4 October 1953) is a [[Swiss people|Swiss]] [[harpist]]. He is generally categorised as a [[new-age music]]ian and uses a modified [[electric harp|electroacoustic harp]] of his own design.{{Cite web|url = http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/vollenweider-still-hits-all-the-right-notes/5682284|title = Vollenweider still hits all the right notes.|date = January 28, 2007|accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = Swissinfo.ch| publisher = Swiss Broadcasting Corporation|last = Léchot|first = Bernard}} He has collaborated with [[Bobby McFerrin]], [[Carly Simon]], [[Luciano Pavarotti]] and in 1987 received a Grammy Award for the album ''[[Down to the Moon]]''.{{Cite web|url = http://www.awardsandshows.com/features/grammy-awards-1987-235.html|title = Grammy Awards 1987|date = |accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = Awards & Shows|publisher = |last = |first = }} Vollenweider's style has been described by ''The New York Times'' as "swirling atmospheric music, which evokes nature, magic and fairy tales".{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/19/arts/electro-acoustic-harpist-to-appear-at-beacon.html?|title = Electro-acoustic Harpist to appear at Beacon|date = October 19, 1984|accessdate = October 6, 2014 |website = The New York Times| publisher = |last = Holden|first = Stephen}} He has toured internationally and produced fourteen regular albums in a career that spans four decades. ==Biography== ===Early life=== Vollenweider was born in 1953 and is the son of Hans Vollenweider (1918–1993), an organist and composer, while his mother was a painter.{{Cite web|url = http://www.bach-cantatas.com/Bio/Vollenweider-Hans.htm|title = Hans Vollenweider (Organ)|date = July 2010|accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = Bach Cantatas website|publisher = Aryeh Oron|last = Montgomery|first = Shaun}}{{Cite journal|url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JCQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT1&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = Vollenweider Doesn't Harp on His Success|last = Sutherland|first = Sam|date = November 17, 1984|journal = Billboard Magazine|accessdate = October 2, 2014|doi = |pmid = }} In 1971, he married Beata, a kindergarten teacher, with whom he has two sons (Jonathan and Sebastian) and a daughter, Noëmi.{{Cite web|url = http://www.morgenpost.de/printarchiv/wwbm/article294357/Dreiundzwanzig-Sonntagsfragen-an-Andreas-Vollenweider-Elektro-Harfenist.html|title = Dreiundzwanzig Sonntagsfragen an Andreas Vollenweider, Elektro-Harfenist|date = November 19, 2006|accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = Berliner Morgenpost|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{Cite web|url = http://www.coopzeitung.ch/125630|title = Andreas Vollenweider: Aus der Reserve|date = August 11, 2011|accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = Coop Zeitung|publisher = |last = Hönle|first = Reinhold}} In 1975, Vollenweider discovered the harp and, finding its traditional versions too limited for his own musical ideas, developed his own style, tailoring the instrument according to his needs. He created the electro-acoustic harp.{{Cite web|url = http://www.zhdk.ch/?ca_avo090|title = ZhdK: Andreas Vollenweider|date = March 2010|accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = Zürcher Hochschule der Künste|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006095544/http://www.zhdk.ch/?ca_avo090|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }} He formed the trio ''Poesie und Musik'' together with Rene Bardet (bass) and Orlando Valentini (guitar), recording interpretations of the poetry of [[François Villon]] and [[Heinrich Heine]], but left in 1978.[https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?method=simpleSearch&query=134321251 ''Poesie und Musik''] in the catalog of the Deutschen National Bibliothek{{Cite web|url = http://www.library.umass.edu/hosted-projects/heine/symposium-talk/|title = Musical settings of Heinrich Heine's political poetry|date = December 12, 1999|accessdate = October 2, 2014|website = UMass Amherst Libraries|publisher = Goethe Institut in New York City|last = Shea|first = Peter W.|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120126105905/http://www.library.umass.edu/hosted-projects/heine/symposium-talk/|archivedate = January 26, 2012|df = }} During this period, Vollenweider also wrote music for film, mainly nature documentaries.{{Cite journal|url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=W-XEpPcqekMC&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = New Sounds|last = Schaefer|first = John|date = October 1985|journal = Spin Magazine|accessdate = October 2, 2014|doi = |pmid = }} ===Career=== ==== 1980s ==== In 1979 he released his solo debut, ''Eine Art Suite in XIII Teilen'' in Switzerland.Discogs.com [http://www.discogs.com/Andreas-Vollenweider-Eine-Art-Suite-In-XIII-Teilen/release/2026596 entry], the album was re-released in 1984. He subsequently began forming his ensemble “Andreas Vollenweider and Friends”, which included Walter Keiser (drums), Pedro Haldemann (percussion), Bobby Reveron (percussion), and Jon Otis (percussion). This five-piece debuted on July 11, 1981 at the Montreux Jazz Festival.Montreux Jazz Live [http://www.montreuxjazzlive.com/concerts-database?title=Vollenweider&field_concert_date_value%5Bvalue%5D%5Byear%5D=# listing]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from 1981. Vollenweider was discovered by the German record-producer and manager Vera Brandes, who oversaw the release of ''[[Behind the Gardens|Behind the Gardens - Behind the Wall - Under the Tree...]]''.{{Cite journal|url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6iQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT27&lpg=PT27&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = Specialized Marketing Examined|last = Sutherland|first = Sam|date = August 10, 1985|journal = Billboard|accessdate = |doi = |pmid = }} through her VeraBra Records. The album was distributed through [[CBS Records International]] and reached 32 in the German album charts in March 1982.Detailed [http://www.chartsurfer.de/artist/andreas-vollenweider/behind-the-gardens-behind-the-wall-under-the-tree-album_fvvhu.html listing] from the German Album chart. The follow-up ''[[Caverna Magica]]'' was recorded in the period May–November 1982 while Vollenweider and his band performed around Europe.Discogs.com [http://www.discogs.com/Andreas-Vollenweider-Caverna-Magica-Under-The-Tree-In-The-Cave/master/82223 listing] for the album. Released in January 1983, the album managed to reach 11 in the German album chart.Detailed German chart [http://www.chartsurfer.de/artist/andreas-vollenweider/caverna-magica-under-the-tree-in-the-cave-album_phvg.html listing]. In 1983, he underlined his commitment to environmental issues with the EP "Pace Verde" in support for [[Greenpeace]], which was accompanied by a video that Vollenweider directed and produced himself. In October of that year he was awarded a Dutch [[Edison Award]] in the ''Instrumental'' category for ''Caverna Magica''.{{Cite book|title = The International Who's Who in Popular Music 2002|last = Gregory|first = Andy|publisher = Europa Publications|year = 2002|isbn = 9781857431612|location = London|pages = 252|url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gZIjT8PgJMEC}} In 1984, the album ''[[White Winds]]'' entered the American billboard chart.Billboard [http://www.billboard.com/artist/279085/andreas-vollenweider/chart chart-listing] for Andreas Vollenweider. Released through [[CBS Masterworks]] in North America, his records remained on catalogue, clocking up to six-figure sales. Vollenweider embarked on his first American tour in November of that year, making his debut at the [[Beacon Theatre (New York City)|Beacon Theatre]], New York.{{Cite journal|url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FCUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA6&lpg=PA6&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = Billboard Magazine|last = |first = |date = November 10, 1986|journal = Billboard Magazine|accessdate = |doi = |pmid = }} It was presented by [[Carly Simon]] who had come across his music a year earlier. She explained that "I knew I had discovered something that was going to change me in a wonderful way, I became so obsessed with his music that anyone who came to my house was introduced to it within the first 10 or 15 minutes". Through CBS she got in contact with the artist and arranged for his American debut. As his instrumental tracks were generally deemed unsuitable for radio, he largely relied on word-of-mouth in gathering an international following. Vollenweider spent much of 1985 on tour, promoting the ''White Winds'' album with his five-piece band.{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1985/04/19/arts/weekender-guide.html|title = Weekender Guide-Friday Electric Harp Sounds|date = April 19, 1985|accessdate = |website = nytimes.com|publisher = New York Times|last = Bennetts|first = Leslie}} The shows were described as a new age experience that combined the use of lights and dry ice while Vollenweider appeared as a "white-clad figure who's poised to drive the audience wild with a harp".{{Cite web|url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20091442,00.html|title = This Twang Is Bound for Glory: Andreas Vollenweider, the Maestro of Mellow, Has Made the Harp Hip|date = August 5, 1985|accessdate = |website = People.com|publisher = People Magazine|last = Russell|first = Lisa}} In 1987, ''[[Down to the Moon|Down To The Moon]]'', which had been originally recorded and released in 1984, received a [[Grammy Award]]. This was followed by tours in Canada, the United States, thirteen European countries, Japan, and Australia. When he composed the music of, and recorded, the dynamic album ''Dancing With The Lion'' in 1988 and 1989, Vollenweider opened his project, for the first time in his career, to numerous guests from a wide range of musical genres. He directed and produced two award-winning videos, one of which was for the title selection; for both videos, he contributed to the storyline, the choreography, and set/costume designs. {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ==== 1990s ==== Vollenweider's double album ''The Trilogy'' (1990), consisted of a selection of the first three albums (''Behind The Gardens'', ''[[Caverna Magica]]'', and ''[[White Winds]]'') and previously unreleased material. In 1991, he followed up with ''[[Book of Roses]]'', which included symphonic orchestral elements for the first time. In 1992, he participated in a benefit show for Chernobyl's children on Moscow's [[Red Square]]. The same year, he won the World Music Award in Monaco. In 1993-94, he produced his first album including vocals. The 1993–94 album ''Eolian Minstrel'' featured contributions from American singers [[Carly Simon]] and [[Eliza Gilkyson]]. The release was followed by worldwide tours. {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 1994, he performed at the Pavarotti and Friends event in [[Modena]], Italy, where he played duets with operatic lyric tenor [[Luciano Pavarotti]] (a native of Modena) and Canadian rock balladeer [[Bryan Adams]]. After conducting tours and open-air shows in Europe and the United States, in 1995 he played in Latin America for the first time. 1995–97 saw Vollenweider playing a series of shows in remarkable locations: a tour of Polish castles, a show with Italian singer/songwriter [[Zucchero]] at the 2500 m high location (at -8° Celsius) of [[Brunico]] in the Southern Alps, and in a giant volcanic cave at [[Lanzarote]]'s Festival Musica Visual. {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 1998, Vollenweider began the recording of ''Kryptos,'' a work for symphonic orchestras and guest virtuosos from all over the world. He initiated a symphonic live project which he called ''Wolkenstein''. In 1999, he returned to free improvisation and intimate musical dialogues with his album ''COSMOPOLY'' He invited friends, including American vocal acrobat [[Bobby McFerrin]], Brazilian cult poet and singer [[Milton Nascimento]], South-African ethno-jazz pianist [[Abdullah Ibrahim]], the 74-year-old Armenian duduk legend [[Djivan Gasparyan]], Galician bag-pipe and whistle virtuoso [[Carlos Núñez Muñoz]], the American singer-songwriter [[Carly Simon]], and American blues-trombone master [[Ray Anderson (musician)|Ray Anderson]], from all over the globe to create “world music”. ==== 2000s ==== Throughout 2000, he traveled with the ''COSMOPOLY'' project in Europe. Its changing configuration of musicians — almost daily — enabled Vollenweider to follow the open concept of the album. In New York City, he and his friends played two concerts for the United States release. Carly Simon joined the group, as did [[Mindy Jostyn]], [[Carlos Núñez Muñoz|Carlos Núñez]], Djivan Gasparyan, [[XiaoJing Wang]] and [[Walter Keiser]]. Concerts in Brazil — with [[Milton Nascimento]] and composer/pianist [[Wagner Tiso]] — followed. In 2001, Vollenweider performed in Bali (Indonesia) at the international conference "song of convergence" with Balinese musicians. He began writing the "symphonic novel" ''Tales of Kira Kutan'', which premiered at the Warsaw Film Music Festival 2001, with the orchestra [[Sinfonia Varsowia]] ([[Yehudi Menuhin]]), conducted by co-orchestrator [[André Bellmont]]. Returning to his native Switzerland, Vollenweider premiered ''Carte blanche'' at the AVO Festival in Basel, where his guests, in addition to a mini orchestra, included [[Abdullah Ibrahim]] and [[David Lindley (musician)|David Lindley]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 2002, he performed at the Budapest Spring Festival in Hungary. Performances of the symphonies ''Tales of Kira Kutan'' and ''Wolkenstein'' at the Festival "Live at Sunset" in Zurich, with Sinfonia Varsovia, followed, as did a European summer tour, with the newly formed AVAF-mini orchestra, that included a performance at the "Big Chill Festival" in England and continued that fall. It was around this time that he collaborated with German film composer [[Hans Zimmer]], in Los Angeles, on the music score for the movie ''[[Tears of the Sun]]'' (starring [[Bruce Willis]] and [[Monica Bellucci]]). In 2003, he continued his work with Zimmer. A performance followed, with his mini orchestra, in [[Johannesburg]] and at the "North Sea Festival" in [[Cape Town]]. {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 2004 and 2005, AVAF continued to increase touring activities in Europe. At this time, Vollenweider's entire catalogue was re-mastered and re-released on new record labels worldwide (USA/Canada: www.kinkoumusic.com; international: www.edel.com). A compilation, ''The Best of "Magic Harp'', was released in the United States and Canada, and ''The Storyteller'' was released in Europe. A four-hour DVD was also produced. He played for the Dalai Lama, when the latter paid a visit in Zurich. In 2005, he released the album ''VOX''. {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In the first three months of 2006, following extensive touring in Europe, Vollenweider conducted his first tour of the US in over ten years, touring from coast to coast. At that time, he also released his first DVD, ''The Magical Journeys of Andreas Vollenweider'', which contained almost four hours of live concerts, documentaries, interviews. During the summer of that year, he recorded a new album, titled ''Midnight Clear'', in which he again collaborated with Carly Simon. (See above for his previous collaborations with her.) The last three months of 2006 saw Vollenweider touring in Europe, in addition to his release of ''Midnight Clear'' on a worldwide basis and that of the DVD ''The Magical Journeys of Andreas Vollenweider'' in the rest of the world. 2007 saw Vollenweider draw his third nomination for a Grammy Award for the soundtrack album of the current DVD release ''The Magical Journeys of Andreas Vollenweider''. Concerts in Europe and the United States followed, as did, in September of that year, the release of the two-CD double album ''Andreas Vollenweider & Friends - 25 Years Live'', which covered the period from 1982 to 2007. {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 2008, during his composition of the music for, and his recording of, the album ''A I R'', Vollenweider was a guest performer at the celebration concert for the 80th birthday of Armenian [[duduk]] legend [[Jivan Gasparyan]]. ==== 2010s ==== In 2010, Vollenweider gave concerts in Eastern and Western Europe. In June, he undertook a special concert project, which he titled ''The Watercourse Way,'' at the Shanghai Centre in Shanghai, China, as part of [[Expo 2010]]. A "Dream Concert" of the extended AVAF followed in August, as did the "Dancing With The Lion Orchestra" concert on the shore of Lake Zurich; it featured a gathering of Vollenweider's musical friends from all corners of the world. In 2011, three decades after his first concert, he accepted the invitation of Montreux Jazz Festival founder Claude Nobs to perform an exclusive jubilee concert, on 7 July, at the 45th such Festival, titled "30 Years Andreas Vollenweider & Friends". It featured special guests [[Richard Bona]] and [[Raul Midon]]. In 2012, he played at the farewell concert for Claude Nobs, who had died in January of that year.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In the same year Vollenweider was granted the Swiss Music Award for "Outstanding Achievement Award" for his continuing life's work. On Christmas Eve, Swiss Television broadcasts the first major documentary devoted to Vollenweider, in which filmmaker Cristina Karrer shows impressing and touching sequences recorded in October 2010 in South Africa. In May 2012 Andreas Vollenweider lends his name to a campaign by ROKPA, a charity he has been working with for decades. Children who had once lived on the streets in Kathmandu, Nepal, visit eight Swiss cities to tell their moving stories using theatre, dance and music, with a changing roster of Swiss musical guests and an equally celebrated line-up of TV moderators. == Style == His style has been described as weaving "elements of European classical and folk music, Third World vocal and percussive effects and natural sound effects into cyclical suites". Vollenweider is perceived as one of the purveyors of the [[New-age music|New Age]] genre, although his earlier recordings appeared on the jazz Billboard chart. The composer found that "what I am doing is really a very old thing, a very 'old age' thing, because I'm doing what people have been doing for thousands of years'. ==Personal life== Vollenweider resides near [[Zurich]]. ===Activism=== In the 1980s, Vollenweider was described as someone whose "politics run to the left, including support for [[Amnesty International]] and [[Greenpeace]]".{{Cite journal|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19860831&id=Vw4iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aKcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5312,5239891|title = Andreas Vollenweider gives harp new image.|last = Hunt|first = Charles|date = August 31, 1986|journal = Reading Eagle |accessdate = October 3, 2014|doi = |pmid = }} He is an outspoken [[Pacifism|pacifist]] and follower of the principles of non-violent conflict management of [[Mahatma Gandhi]].{{cite web| url= http://www.vollenweider.com| website= vollenweider.com| title= Andreas Vollenweider website| date= | access-date= }} ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''Eine Art Suite in XIII Teilen'' (1979) * ''[[Behind the Gardens|Behind the Gardens – Behind the Wall – Under the Tree]]'' (1981) * ''[[Caverna Magica]]'' (1983) * ''[[White Winds|White Winds (Seeker's Journey)]]'' (1984) * ''[[Down to the Moon]]'' (1986) * ''[[Dancing with the Lion]]'' (1989) * ''Traumgarten'' (collaboration with his father, organist Hans Vollenweider, 1990) * ''[[Book of Roses]]'' (1991) * ''[[Eolian Minstrel]]'' (1993) * ''Kryptos'' (1997) * ''[[Cosmopoly]]'' (1999) * ''Vox'' (CD + DVD, 2004) * ''[[Midnight Clear]]'' (2006, featuring [[Carly Simon]]) * ''AIR'' (2009, featuring [[Xavier Naidoo]]) ===Compilations=== * ''The Trilogy'' (compilation of ''Behind the Gardens,'' ''Caverna Magica,'' ''White Winds,'' and "Pace Verde," with selections from ''Eine Art Suite,'' 1990) * ''Andreas Vollenweider & Friends – Live 1982–1994'' (1994) * ''The Essential Andreas Vollenweider'' (compilation, 2005) * ''The Storyteller'' (compilation, 2005) * ''Magic Harp'' (compilation, CD + DVD, 2005) * ''The Magical Journeys of Andreas Vollenweider'' (soundtrack for the DVD ''The Magical Journeys of Andreas Vollenweider,'' 2006) * ''Andreas Vollenweider & Friends 25 Years Live 1982-2007'' (2009) ===Singles=== * "Pace Verde" (single for [[Greenpeace]], 1983) * "The Woman and the Stone" (1984) * "Night Fire Dance" (1986) * "Dancing with the Lion" (1989), # 25 Billboard Hot Adult Contemporary charts, dated 8/26/1989 Image:AVollenweider.jpg| Image:vollenweider_TV.png| Image:macufe4.jpg| Image:palermototale.png| Image:vollenweider_symphonic.jpg| revision.text:
'''Bibi Khānoom Astarābādi'''''Bibi'' (بی بی) means Matron, "a married woman especially one characterized by dignity, staid discreet behaviour, and plump motherly appearance" (''[[OED]]''), Venerable lady or Grandmother. ''Khatoon'' (خاتون) is a variant of the word ''Khanoom'' (خانوم), or ''Khanom'' (خانم). Any one of these three words (in particular the latter one) is often added to a woman's name in token of respect; it therefore need not be part of the official name of a woman. The official use of ''Khatoon'' is rare, if not obsolete, in the present-day Iran, and of the remaining two, ''Khanom'' is formal and ''Khanoom'' rather colloquial. The words ''Khatoon'', ''Khanoom'' and ''Khanom'', the feminine forms of the word ''Khan'', are of [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]] origin.''Astarabadi'' (استرآبادی) refers to the people of ''Astarabad'' (استرآباد), the modern city of [[Gorgan]] and the capital of the [[Golestan Province]] of [[Iran]]. ({{lang-fa|بی بی خانم استرآبادی}})‎ (1858/59–1921) was a notable [[Demography of Iran|Iranian]] writer, [[satirist]], and one of the pioneering figures in the women's movement of Iran. Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi was born to the family of ''Mohammad Baqer Khan Astarabadi'', one of the notable men of Astarabad (the present-day [[Gorgan]]), and ''Khadijeh Khanom'' (خديجه خانم), known as''Bāji'' means both Female servant, and Sister. In the latter case it is a variant of the word ''Ābji'', Sister. The writer of these lines is not familiar with the etymology of these words, however it is disconcertingly plausible that at some point in history parents and/or brothers may have come to see their daughters and/or sisters respectively as female servants in the household. What is more likely, however, is that ''Bāji'' simply means ''Sister'' and that its meaning as ''Female servant'' may be attributable to the fact that through referring to a female servant as ''Bāji'' one has intended, and intends, to be familial and convey the implicit verbal assurance that she would not be subjected to sexual harassment by the male members of the family; it is rather common in Iran that one conveys a similar statement by addressing a member of the opposite sex as ''brother'' or ''sister'', as the case may be (when used inappropriately or in excess, such use may be viewed as patronising however). ''Mollah Bāji'' (ملاباجی), one of the companions of ''Shokuh ol-Saltaneh'' (شکوه السلطنه), wife to [[Nasser al-Din Shah Qajar]]. The title ''Mollah Bāji'' (see ''[[Mullah|Mollah]]'') is indicative that she must have been educated and in charge of more than the daily household chores of Shah's Court. Indeed, she has been in charge of the education of the children in the court of Nasser al-Din Shah. At the age of 22, Bibi Khatoon married ''Musa Khan Vaziri'' who was a prominent official in the ''[[Persian Cossack Brigade]]''. They had seven children, of whom the most distinguished are ''[[Ali-Naqi Vaziri|Colonel Ali-Naqi Vaziri]]'' (musicologist, composer, a celebrated player of the [[Tar (lute)|tar]], and the founder of the Academy of Music of Iran as well of Iran's National Orchestra), and ''Hasan Vaziri'' (an artistic painter).''Bibi Khanom Astarabadi (Gorgani)'', A short biography of Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi (in Persian), containing some transcripted material from an interview by ''Deutsche Welle'' with Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah (دكتر مه لقا ملاح), maternal granddaughter of Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi ([http://www.shomaliha.com/zanan/bibi.html Shomaliha.com]). Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah (دكتر مه لقا ملاح), founder and director of Iran's "Women's Society against Environmental Pollution" (founded in 1992 to educate children and mothers, as well as state's officials, about dangers of environmental pollution){{cite web|title=The Iran Initiative'', The Fellowship of Reconciliation (FOR) - For a World of Peace, Justice and Nonviolence, Report 6, May 2006 |url=http://www.forusa.org/programs/iran/may06-6.htm |publisher=Forusa.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711145614/https://www.forusa.org/programs/iran/may06-6.htm |archivedate=11 July 2007 |df=dmy }} is the maternal granddaughter of Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi.For an interview, made in 2006 by ''Deutsche Welle'', with Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah, see External Links. Bibi Khatoon was one of the influential figures in the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution|Iranian constitutional revolution]] in the late 19th and the early 20th century. She founded the first school for girls (named ''The School for Girls'' — دبستان دوشیزگان) in the modern history of Iran and wrote numerous articles in defence of the right of girls to receive universal education. Her articles appeared in such newspapers as ''Tamaddon'' (تمدن - Civilization), ''Habl al-Matin'' (حبل المتين - Firm Rope) and ''Majles'' (مجلس - Parliament). Bibi Khatoon is also known for her book ''Ma'ayeb al-Rejal'' (معايب الرجال - Failings of Men),The extant translation of the title ''Ma'ayeb al-Rejal'' (معايب الرجال) as ''Vices of Men'', or even ''The Vices of Men'', is incorrect when the contents of the book are disregarded. The word ''Ma'ayeb'' (معايب), or ''Oyoub'' (عیوب), is the plural of the Persian (in fact [[Arabic language|Arabic]]) word ''Eyb'' (عیب), which refers to a shortcoming or a failing, rather than a vice ''per se''. To clarify, according to ''OED'', ''Failing'' means "A defect of character; a weakness", whereby ''Failings'' is seen to be an apt choice for ''Ma'ayeb''. In contrast, according to the same dictionary, ''Vice'' means "Extreme moral corruption; depravity; evil; grossly immoral or degrading habits or conduct". The word ''Fesq'' (فسق) would be appropriately translated as ''Vice''. Only through taking the contents of the book into account, can one consider ''Vices'' as an appropriate translation of ''Ma'ayeb''. The books in section ''Further reading'' should be illuminating. which was a critical response to the pamphlet ''Ta'deeb al-Nesvan'' (تاديب النسوان - Edification of Women)In general, ''Ta'deeb'' (تاديب) also means ''Disciplinary punishment'', reflecting the implicit assumption that the latter would lead to edification. by an anonymous author. ''Ma'ayeb al-Rejal'' was published in 1895, eleven years before the inauguration of Iran's system of constitutional monarchy in 1906 by the decree of [[Mozzafar al-Din Shah|Mozaffar al-Din Shah Qajar]].''Bibi Khanom Astarabadi (Gorgani)'', ''ibid.'' This book is considered by some as the first declaration of women's rights in the recent history of Iran. ==''The School for Girls'' (دبستان دوشیزگان)== Founded in 1907 at the residential home of Bibi Khatoon in [[Tehran]], it was attended both by young girls and their mothers as well as grandmothers, for some of the latter it may have been a unique opportunity for obtaining formal education for the first time in their lives. The school was equipped with such facilities as may be taken for granted from the present-day perspective (such as desks), however it should be borne in mind that this school provision was part of Bibi Khatoon's residential home and not part of a purpose-built educational facility.''The School for Girls'' (مدرسه دوشيزگان). A programme celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Constitutional Revolution of Iran with an interview with Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah (دكتر مه لقا ملاح), maternal granddaughter of Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi, 11 August 2006 ([http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2411784,00.html Deutsche Welle]). The date 1907, indicated above, is somewhat uncertain to the present writer; according to Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah, "This school was established before the [[Iranian Constitutional Revolution|Constitutional Revolution]] (انقلاب مشروط)", which took place between 1905 and 1911; the [[Majlis of Iran|First Majlis]] was elected in 1906, to be made defunct through the [[coup d'état]] of [[Mohammad Ali Shah Qajar|Mohammad-Ali Shah Qajar]] in June 1908. This clearly testifies to Bibi Khatoon's wholehearted dedication to the cause of women's education in Iran.
'''Advertisement'''
''The School for Girls'' A new school, named ''The School for Girls'' [دبستان دوشیزگان], has been opened near the old gate of Mahmmadieh, the Hāji Mohammad-Hossein market. This school consists of a large courtyard and numerous rooms equipped with all necessary school outfits. For the opening of this school five female teachers [معلمه] have been appointed, each responsible for one subject, such as ''Nokhost-nameh''According to Ms Farnaz Seifi (private communication), ''Nokhost-nameh'' consisted of a series of books, written by Matavous Khan Mālekiāns, that were commonly used at elementary schools of the time in Iran. These books were further supplemented with manuals for teachers. [نخست نامه], Writing/Calligraphy [مشق قلم], History of Iran [تاریخ ایران], Reading [قرائت], Cookery book [کتاب طباخی], Law [قانون], Religion [مذهب], Geography [جغرافیا], Science of Arithmetic [علم حساب]. Teaching will be adapted to the learning ability of each girl or woman. In addition, a location has been set aside for teaching in manual arts, such as knitting [کاموا دوزی], gold embroidery [زری دوزی], silk embroidery [خامه دوزی], sewing [خیاطی], etc., and all these teachers are womenfolk [طایفه اناثیه] and with the exception of an aged porter [پیرمرد قاپوچی], no other man will be in the School. Students between the ages of seven and twelve will be accepted. Elementary class [اطاق ابتدائی] is for fifteen ''[[Iranian qiran|qeran]]'' per month, practical class [اطاق عملی] for twenty-five ''qeran'' per month. Discount is offered to those in reduced circumstances [فقرأ]. For every two students [from the same family] one will be accepted free of charge. It is hoped that thousands of schools such as this one are to be inaugurated in our dear motherland [وطن عزیز ما]. Signature: Bibi Khanom Astarabadi.{{cite web |title=Emshaspandan |date=Monday 10 ''Ordi'behesht'' 1386 |url=http://www.farnaaz.info/herstory/003066.html |publisher=Farnaaz.info |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070717115833/http://www.farnaaz.info/herstory/003066.html |archivedate=17 July 2007 |df=dmy }} For details concerning the word ''Emshās'pandān'' (امشاسپندان) see Masoud Partovi, ''The New Year's Haftsin and the Figure Seven'' in ''Persian History'' (''Hamshahri'', No. 2669, p. 15, 7 March 2002). ([http://imp.lss.wisc.edu/~aoliai/historypage/thenewyearhaftsin.htm Department of Languages and Cultures of Asia, The University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States of America].) Briefly, there have been seven ''Emshās'pandān''s, namely, ''Ahurā Mazdā'' (or ''Ormazd'') and its great Holy Angles known as ''Bahman'', ''Ordi'behesht'', ''Shahri'var'', ''Es'fand'', ''Khor'dād'' and ''Amor'dād''.Translation from [[Persian language|Persian]] by --BF. (Published in the ''Majles'' daily newspaper of 28 March 1907).Ms Farnarz Seifi, private communication.
The subjects taught at this school consisted of, in alphabetic order, [[Arabic language]], [[Arithmetic]], [[Cookery]], [[Geography]], [[History]], [[Law]], [[Music]], [[Persian literature]], and [[Religion]], to name but some. It is relevant to point out that in 1936, almost thirty years after the establishment of ''The School for Girls'', 12 women were for the first time admitted to [[University of Tehran]], who entered all faculties.{{cite web |author=Massoume Price |title=History of Ancient Medicine in Mesopotamia and Iran |publisher=Iran Chamber Society |year= 2001 |url= http://www.iranchamber.com/history/articles/ancient_medicine_mesopotamia_iran.php}} According to the official data provided by Iran's ministry of higher education, at the turn of the present century some 70% of all students in higher education were women; according to the same data, however, by the same time only 20% of the [[PhD]] positions at academic institutions were occupied by women.These statements need to be verified, as the present writer is not in possession of the original reports containing these data and relies solely on secondary sources. The historical site of ''The School for Girls'' survived in its original form for some 22 years following the death of Bibi Khatoon in 1921; in 1943 this site was sold (for 25,000 [[Iranian toman|Tumans]]) by the extant members of Bibi Khatoon's direct family.''The School for Girls'' (مدرسه دوشيزگان), ''ibid.'' ==Activities in support of the Constitutional Revolution== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} ==On ''Ta'deeb al-Nesvan'' (تاديب النسوان - Edification of Women)== According to [[Ebrahim Nabavi]],{{cite web |author=Ebrahim Nabavi |title=Bibi Khanom and the Unknown Prince (بی بی خانم و شاهزاده گمنام) |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |language=Persian |date=26 July 2006 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/worldnews/story/2006/07/060722_mv-constitution-en-bibikhatun.shtml}}The present writer has consulted neither ''Ta'deeb al-Nesvan'' nor ''Ma'ayeb al-Rejal''. Some familiarity with this genre of the literature of the time suggests however that ''Ta'deeb al-Nesvan'' may not have been more than a prank by a member of Iran's aristocracy of the time. ''Ta'deeb al-Nesvan'', published in 1288 [[Hijri year|AH]] (1895), is a small booklet authored by one of the princes of the [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]] Court, "who must have feared his wife so greatly that he has not had the courage to put his name on it as its author" (in other words, the author of the book is an anonymous Prince). A short summary of the main recommendations in this book, aimed at the "edification" of women, is as follows:Ebrahim Nabavi, ''ibid.'' #Woman is a being who similar to a child must be educated by a man. #Salvation of woman is conditional upon her absolute obedience to her husband. #Woman must never ask a favour from her husband; it is up to husband to deign to confer favours to his wife. #The duty of woman at home is provision of conditions that are conducive to her husband's tranquility. #The aim of matrimony consists of gratification of the husband's sexual desires. #Woman must at all times be abashed, except in bed. #Woman must not speak during meals. #Woman must, like an ailing individual, walk slowly. : Etc. The Vices of Men (Ma'ayib al-Rijal) (1887),a pungent satire, is in fact an answer to an earlier work entitled The Education of Women (Ta'dib al-Niswan (translated into English by E. Powys Mathers in his Eastern Love, vol.iii, London, 1904). The anonymous writer of the latter seems to be a chauvinistic prince, and following the medieval tradition that was not accepted by Shia Muslim clerics. Bibi Khanum's answers to such absurdities are scathingly indignant. She writes that "genius of the world and unique writer of our times" seems strangely bereft of his senses. "He should have first corrected his own vices and then given us advice. One who has no share of existence, how can he inspire life? ...He regards himself as 'Westernized' and 'civilized,' but in fact, he is not even 'half-civilized.'(سیویلیزه و نیم ویلیزه) Does he not know that Europeans treat their women like flowers, and women freely associate with men?" The indication that the author was westernised clearly indicates, he must have been from the so-called western influenced intellectuals. Strangely enough at the time women had very few rights in the west in comparison to Iran and only in some parts of the western world had been able to claim their rights to inheritance. These two works were published by Hasan Javadi as "Two Qajar Essays on Men and Women: Ta'dib al-Nivan and Ma'ayib al-Rijal" in Washington in 1992. رویایی زن و مرد در عصر قاجار در عصر قاجار: دو رساله تادیب النسوان و معایب الرجال ==Response of Bibi Khatoon: ''Ma'ayeb al-Rejal'' (معايب الرجال - Failings of Men)== According to Ebrahim Nabavi,Ebrahim Nabavi, ''ibid. ''Ma'ayeb al-Rejal'' consists of two main parts, in one of which Bibi Khatoon responds directly to the contents of ''Ta'deeb al-Nesvan'', and in the other she describes the conditions prevailing in the men's social gatherings of her time. True to her usual style of writing, Bibi Khatoon's tone in this book is derisive. [To be extended at a later occasion.] ==See also== *[[Forough Azarakhshi]] *[[Farrokhroo Parsa|Farrokhroo Pārsā]] *[[Intellectual movements in Iran]] *[[Iranian women]] *[[One Million Signatures]] *[[Persian Constitutional Revolution]] *[[Persian women's movement]] ==Notes and references== ==Further reading== * [[Afsaneh Najmabadi]], ''Women with Mustaches and Men without Beards: Gender and Sexual Anxieties of Iranian Modernity'' (University of California Press, Berkeley, 2005). {{ISBN|0-520-24263-7}} * Afsaneh Najmabadi, editor, ''Bibi Khanum Astarabadi's Ma'ayib al-Rijal: Vices of Men'' (Midland Printers, Chicago, 1992). * Hasan Javadi, Manijeh Marashi, and Simin Shekrloo, editors, ''Ta'dib al-Nisvan va Ma'ayib al-Rijal'' [Disciplining of Women and Vices of Men] (Jahan Books, Maryland, 1992). * ''The education of women & the vices of men: two Qajar tracts'', transl. and introd. by Hasan Javadi and Willem Floor (Syracuse Univ. Press, Syracuse NY, 2010). {{ISBN|978-0-8156-3240-5}} * Jasmin Khosravie, ''Die Sünden der Männer – Konzepte von Weiblichkeit im Spiegel der Lebenswelt von Bibi Khanum Astarabadi (st. 1921)'', in: S. Conermann & S. von Hees (ed.): Islamwissenschaft als Kulturwissenschaft: Historische Anthropologie. Ansätze und Möglichkeiten (pp. 235–262), (EB-Publishers, Hamburg 2007). ==External links== {{commons category|Bibikhanom Astarabadi}} * Ebrahim Nabavi, ''Bibi Khanom and the Unknown Prince'' (بی بی خانم و شاهزاده گمنام), BBC Persian, Wednesday 26 July 2006 ([http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/worldnews/story/2006/07/060722_mv-constitution-en-bibikhatun.shtml BBC Persian]). * ''The School for Girls'' (مدرسه دوشيزگان). A programme celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Constitutional Revolution of Iran with an interview with Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah (دكتر مه لقا ملاح), maternal granddaughter of Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi, 11 August 2006 ([http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2411784,00.html Deutsche Welle]). At the time of interview, Dr Mallah is 90 years old. * ''Bibi Khanom Astarabadi (Gorgani)'', A short biography of Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi (in Persian), containing some transcribed material from the above-mentioned interview with ''Deutsche Welle'' of Dr Mah-Laghā Mallah ([http://www.shomaliha.com/zanan/bibi.html Shomaliha.com]). {{Persian Constitutional Revolution Persions}} {{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Astarabadi, Bibi Khatoon}} [[Category:Iranian satirists]] [[Category:Iranian essayists]] [[Category:1858 births]] [[Category:1921 deaths]] [[Category:Iranian women's rights activists]] [[Category:Iranian writers]] [[Category:Iranian women writers]] [[Category:Iranian democracy activists]] [[Category:People of the Persian Constitutional Revolution]] [[Category:Iranian women essayists]] [[Category:Women satirists]] [[Category:19th-century Iranian women writers]] [[Category:20th-century Iranian women writers]] [[Category:19th-century Iranian writers]] [[Category:20th-century Iranian writers]]

revision.text:
{{Spanish name|Jacob|Soledad}} [[File:Don Camilo Jacob at Quince Martires Monument.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Don Camilo Jacob at Quince Martires Monument]] '''Camilo Jacob''' '''y Soledad'''<ref name="ADRADOS">{{cite book|last1=Adrados|first1=Jerry|title=Daratangan na Olay: Common Language of Bikolnon|date=2012|publisher=Other Option Promotions|location=Tabaco City|isbn=978-971-95468-0-1|page=162}}</ref> (1856<ref name = "ADRADOS"/> - January 4, 1897) was a [[Bicolano people|Bicol]]ano hero, martyr<ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES">{{cite web|author= |url=http://pinoyfolktales.blogspot.com/2013/01/filipino-martyr-camilo-jacob.html |title=Pinoy Folk Tales: Filipino Martyr: CAMILO JACOB |website=Pinoyfolktales.blogspot.com |date=2013-01-18 |accessdate=2017-03-17}}</ref><ref name="INQUIRER.NET">{{cite web|author1=Juan Escandor Jr. |author2=Shiena M. Barrameda |url=https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/610640/15-bicolano-martyrs-given-honors-in-june-12-rites-in-naga-city/amp |title=15 Bicolano martyrs given honors in June 12 rites in Naga City | Inquirer News |website=Newsinfo.inquirer.net |date= |accessdate=2017-03-17}}</ref><ref name = "KAHIMYANG">{{cite web|url=https://kahimyang.com/kauswagan/articles/1377/today-in-philippine-history-january-4-1897-11-of-the-15-bicol-martyrs-were-executed-in-bagumbayan |title=11 of 15 Bicol Martyrs were executed in Bagumbayan January 4, 1897 |website=Kahimyang.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-17}}</ref> and revolutionary.<ref name = "NAGA.GOV.PH">{{citeweb|url=https://naga.gov.ph/naga-smiles-2/bikol-honors-its-15-martyrs-of-the-1896-revolution/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826081059/http://naga.gov.ph/naga-smiles-2/bikol-honors-its-15-martyrs-of-the-1896-revolution/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-26 |title=Bikol honors its 15 martyrs of the 1896 revolution |website= Naga City Government website |accessdate=2017-03-12 }}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.voxbikol.com/article/bikol-honors-its-15-martyrs-the1896-revolution] |author=Vox Bikol |title=Bikol honors its 15 martyrs of the 1896 revolution |website=Vox Bikol |date=2012-01-07 |accessdate=2017-03-21}}</ref><ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/><ref name = "NHCP">{{cite web|url=http://nhcp.gov.ph/nhcp-unveils-camilo-jacob-historical-marker/ |title=NHCP unveils Camilo Jacob historical marker - National Historical Commission of the Philippines |website=Nhcp.gov.ph |date=2017-03-06 |accessdate=2017-03-17}}</ref> He was also known as one of the 11 among the [[Fifteen Martyrs of Bicol]] who were executed in Bagumbayan (Luneta), now [[Rizal Park]], by Spanish authorities at the end of 19th century during the [[Philippine revolution]].
==Life== Being a native, he grew up and was raised in [[Polangui, Albay|Polangui]], in the province of [[Albay]]. At the time he was implicated, he was already pursuing a career as a successful professional,<ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/> and commercial<ref name = "NAGA.GOV.PH"/> photographer, thereby maintaining his photographic studio at [[Nueva Cáceres|Nueva Caceres]], now [[Naga City, Camarines Sur|Naga City]]. Since at that time, photography was considered as novelty and as one of the luxuries, it made him well known amongst clients who were from families of government officials and businessmen who wanted their portraits taken.<ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/>
==Involvement in the Philippine Revolution== The onset of Philippine revolution on the last part of 1896 raised concerns among the Spanish authorities of its possible outbreak in the Bicol region. Thus, those who were liberal-minded were bitterly persecuted on grounds of not just holding separatist ideologies but on advocating the overthrowing of Spain's authority in the Philippines.<ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/> These persecutions involved businessmen and professionals, mostly adherents to Masonry and members of the clergy.<ref name = "NAGA.GOV.PH"/><ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/> Among the arrested was Vicente Lukban, head of Masonic chapter, ''Triangulo Bikol'', belonging to the Masonic lodge, ''La Luz Oriente'', which, upon interrogation, implicated Jacob as one of the active member and supporter of the [[Katipunan]].<ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/>
==Arrest, trials and execution== On September 19, 1896, he, along with many others accused with rebellion and sedition, he was arrested. Upon arrest, each of them were hung by their thumbs of fingers and beaten up, starved and insulted.<ref name = "PINOYFOLKTALES"/> Then they were sent and brought to Manila, for trial by the Provincial Junta of Camarines Sur headed by then Governor Julian Ocampo,<ref name = "NAGA.GOV.PH"/><ref name = "INQUIRER.NET"/> on board steamer ''Isarog'' and imprisoned in ''Bilibid'' only to be tortured again. Even so, they were tortured and all, Jacob remained an exemplary as "the prisoner who suffered the most torture with great fortitude".<ref name = "KAHIMYANG"/> After they were sentenced on accusations against them, on January 4, 1897, 5 days after [[Jose Rizal|Jose Rizal’s]] execution, Jacob, along with 10 others were marched to the site and was executed with firing squad,<ref name = "NAGA.GOV.PH"/> as their families stood watch amongst the crowd. Then the Spanish authorities immediately ordered the families to bury them on that day to prevent outpouring sympathizers.<ref name = "INQUIRER.NET"/>
==Commemoration== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Camilo Jacob Historical Marker at Polangui, Albay.jpg|thumb|Camilo Jacob Marker]] --> On March 7, 2017, the [[National Historical Commission of the Philippines|National Historical Commission of the Philippines]] (NHCP) unveiled the Camilo Jacob Historical marker in [[Polangui, Albay]] and turned it over to the local government of [[Polangui]].<ref name = "NHCP"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jacob, Camilo}} [[Category:Bicolano people]] [[Category:People of the Philippine Revolution]]
[[Category:1897 deaths]] [[Category:1856 births]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox writer | name = Eckhard Supp | image = Eckhard_Supp.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Eckhard Supp | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1950|8|23}} | birth_place = [[Bad Ems]], [[Germany]] | alma_mater = [[Johann Wolfgang Goethe-Universität Frankfurt am Main]]([[DPhil]]) | residence = [[Hamburg]], ([[Germany]]) | occupation = journalist, wine critic | nationality = German | subject = journalism, wine | influences = | influenced = | awards = }}
'''Eckhard Supp''' (born 23 August 1950 at [[Bad Ems]], [[Germany]]) is a German non-fiction author, journalist, photographer and [[wine]] [[critic]].
==Biography== From 1969 to 1975, Eckhard Supp studied Pedagogics, Political Science, History, Philosophy and Sociology at the [[Johann Wolfgang Goethe-Universität Frankfurt am Main]], [[Germany]]. In 1985, he took a doctoral degree (DPhil) in sociology with a thesis on Australia's aborigenes (Australiens Aborigines – Ende der Traumzeit).
In 1975 and 1976, he collaborated in the compilation of an index & glossary for the complete edition of German philosopher [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]].
From 1977 to 1984, he lived and worked as a freelance photographer and journalist in [[Paris]] (France), where he cooperated with the French photo agency [[Rapho (agency)|Rapho]]. From 1984 to 1989 he lived in [[Rome]] (Italy). His photoreportages took him to numerous European countries as well as to Angola, South Africa, Namibia, Australia, Mauritius, the Seychelles, the U.S. and Chile. In 2015 his photographs were exhibited at Paris, Frankfurt, Hamburg, Naples, Rome and in the U.S. (Indiana University, Bloomington). His photographs of Naples were exhibited together with the work of [[Helmut Newton]], [[Robert Mapplethorpe]], [[Gianni Berengo Gardin]], [[Verena von Gagern]] and others it the retrospective exhibition BLOW UP - Fotografia a Napoli 1980-1990.
Since 1986, Eckhard Supp writes among other topics about food and wine. In 1992 he founded the publishing house of ENO Verlag, specialized in wine publications.
From 2003 to 2009, he was the editor and main author of two special volumes on wine and cooking for ''The [[Brockhaus Enzyklopädie|Brockhaus]] Enzyklopädie'', a German encyclopedia.
In 2005, he was editor-in-chief for two cooking magazines, ''essen & trinken'' and ''schöner essen'' at Gruner + Jahr publishers.
Since February 2015, Eckhard Supp is publisher and editor-in-chief of the quarterly magazine "enos - of wine, people and cultures".
==Bibliography==
* ''Ils vivent autrement''. Paris 1982. (with I. Diener) * ''Australiens Aborigines – Ende der Traumzeit''. Bonn 1985. * ''Azania''. Berlin 1986. * ''Rom''. Hamburg 1990. * ''Seychellen''. Ostfildern 1991. * ''Wein für Einsteiger''. München 1992. * ''Enzyklopädie des Italienischen Weins''. Offenbach 1995. * ''Enzyklopädie des Österreichischen Weins''. Offenbach 1996. * ''Wein für Einsteiger – Italien''. München 1997. * ''Enzyklopädie des Deutschen Weins''. Offenbach 1997. * ''Eno-Ratgeber: 100 Tips zum Wein''. Offenbach 1999. * ''Eno-Ratgeber: ABC Italien''. Offenbach 2000. * ''Rotwein-Lexikon''. Hamburg 2001. * ''Weißwein-Lexikon''. Hamburg 2002. * ''Eno-Ratgeber: ABC Deutschland, Österreich und Schweiz''. Göttingen 2002. * ''Der Brockhaus – Wein''. Mannheim 2004, 2nd, completely revised edition 2009. * ''Weinglossar für Globetrotter''. Göttingen 2004. * ''Wein – Das große Einsteigerbuch''. Göttingen 2006. * ''Der Brockhaus – Kochkunst''. Mannheim 2007. * ''Duden - Wörterbuch Wein''. Mannheim 2011. * ''Duden - Wörterbuch Kochkunst''. Mannheim 2011.
Eckhard Supp is the author or co-author of more than 30 wine and travel books.
==References==
* boersenblatt.net: Eckhard Supp neuer Chefredakteur von "essen & trinken" [http://www.boersenblatt.net/80331/] * presseportal.de: Eckhard Supp neuer Chefredakteur von "essen & trinken" [http://www.presseportal.de/pm/6562/629741/dr-eckhard-supp-neuer-chefredakteur-fuer-essen-trinken] * Der Freitag: Vom Sterben großer Weine [http://www.freitag.de/autoren/eckhard-supp/vom-sterben-grosser-weine-und-des-gesunden-menschenverstands] * Der Freitag: Das Internet und die Medien [http://www.freitag.de/autoren/eckhard-supp/das-internet-und-die-medien-2013-1-presse-weinpresse-beweinte-presse] * Amanda Hayman: Indigenous voices [http://blogs.slq.qld.gov.au/indigenous-voices/2012/08/23/collecting-for-our-next-exhibition/]
==External links== * [http://www.enobooks.de ENO WorldWine] * Werkstatt-Verlag: Eckhard Supp [http://www.werkstatt-verlag.de/?q=taxonomy/term/246] * [http://www.loeildelaphotographie.com/en/2015/01/12/article/26961/blow-up-fotografia-a-napoli-1980-1990 BLOW UP – Fotografia a Napoli 1980-1990]
{{Authority control}}
