{{Infobox officeholder |name=Geno Martini |image= |alt= |caption= |order=24th |office=Mayor of Sparks |term_start=February 22, 2005 |term_end= |predecessor=[[Tony Armstrong (politician)|Tony Armstrong]] |successor= |order2= |office2=[[Sparks, Nevada|Member of the Sparks City Council]] from Ward 3 |term_start2=November 9, 1998 |term_end2=February 22, 2005 |predecessor2= |successor2= |birth_name=Geno R. Martini |birth_date={{birth date and age|1946|1|19}} |birth_place=[[Reno, Nevada]], U.S. |residence=[[Sparks, Nevada]], U.S. |alma_mater=[[University of Nevada, Reno]] |profession=[[Politician]] and former [[Businesspeople|businessman]] |party=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse=Ruth Martini |website={{Official website|http://www.mayormartini.com/}}{{dead link|date=December 2013}} }} '''Geno R. Martini''' (born January 19, 1946) is an American [[politician]] and former [[Businesspeople|businessman]]. He is the current and the 24th Mayor of [[Sparks, Nevada]] and chairman of the [[Truckee Meadows Water Authority]]. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://dailysparkstribune.com/view/full_story/2546395/article-Remembering-%E2%80%98the-people%E2%80%99s-mayor%E2%80%99|title=Remembering ‘the people’s mayor’|date=January 29, 2005|newspaper=[[Daily Sparks Tribune]]|accessdate=November 28, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rgj.com/article/20100528/NEWS19/100528032/Sparks-mayoral-primary-Q-Geno-Martini-Gene-Newhall-Ron-Schmitt |title=Sparks mayoral primary: Q&A with Geno Martini, Gene Newhall and Ron Schimtt|date=May 28, 2010|newspaper=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|accessdate=November 28, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kolotv.com/home/headlines/122367384.html|title=Sparks Mayor Geno Martini Recovering Back Home|date=May 21, 2011|publisher=[[KOLO-TV]]|accessdate=November 28, 2012}}</ref>
On November 13, 2015, Martini announced that he was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bessette|first=Chanelle|url=http://www.rgj.com/story/news/2015/11/13/sparks-mayor-martini-announces-parkinsons-diagnosis/75708138/|title=Sparks Mayor Geno Martini announces Parkinson's diagnosis|date=November 13, 2015|newspaper=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pearce|first=Ed|url=http://www.kolotv.com/home/headlines/Sparks-Mayor-Martini-Living-With-Parkinsons-Staying-On-The-Job-348098081.html|title=Sparks Mayor Martini, Living With Parkinson's, Staying On The Job|date=November 13, 2015|publisher=[[KOLO-TV]]|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>
On April 6, 2017, it was announced that Martini was recovering from surgery to relieve the issues of [[Parkinson's disease]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Balez|first=Kenzie|url=http://mynews4.com/news/local/sparks-mayor-recovering-after-recent-surgery|title=Sparks Mayor recovering after recent surgery|date=April 6, 2017|publisher=[[KRNV-DT]]|accessdate=April 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Nelson|first=Paul|url=http://www.ktvn.com/story/35116518/sparks-mayor-optimistic-after-surgery|title=Sparks Mayor Optimistic After Surgery|date=April 10, 2017|publisher=[[KTVN]]|accessdate=April 11, 2017}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Delft14.JPG|thumb|Statue of Gertrude van der Oosten in Delft]] '''Gertrude van der Oosten''' (or '''Gertrude of Delft''') was born in Voorburcht in the [[County of Holland]], whose location is unclear, and died at [[Delft]], 6 January 1358. She was a Dutch [[Beguine]] and was considered a [[mysticism|mystic]], who had received the [[Stigmata]].
==Life==
Gertrude was born of peasant parents, and entered into [[domestic service]] at Delft. Her surname of ''van Ooten'', or "of the East", came from her custom of singing a hymn which began: ''Het daghet in den Oosten'', i.e., "Daylight breaks in the East", which she is thought to have composed herself.
After living a pious life for many years, Gertrude obtained admission into the [[beguinage]] in [[Delft]]. Here, though not a [[nun]], or bound by [[religious vows]], she profited by the ample opportunities for [[contemplation]] afforded by life in this community. She had great devotion to the mysteries of the [[Incarnation]], especially to the [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]] of Christ. She is believed to have received the [[Stigmata]]. She begged God that this grace might be withdrawn, and her prayer was granted to the degree that the blood ceased to flow, but the marks of the Stigmata remained. At the same time she displayed the gift of [[prophecy]].
Gertrude died on the [[feast day]] of the [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] and was buried in the Church of St. Hippolytus in Delft, as that beguinage did not have its own church or cemetery. Her name has never been inscribed in the ''[[Roman Martyrology]]'', though she is commemorated in various others, and her [[cult (religious practice)#Roman Catholic ''cultus''|''cultus'']] is a purely local one.
==References== {{reflist}}
;Attribution *{{Catholic|wstitle=Ven. Gertrude van der Oosten}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oosten, Gertrude Van Der}} [[Category:1358 deaths]] [[Category:People from Delft]] [[Category:Beguines and Beghards]] [[Category:Roman Catholic mystics]] [[Category:Flemish Christian mystics]] [[Category:Stigmatics]] [[Category:14th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]

revision.comment: Added "Anglican communion" because there are Anglican churches dedicated to St. Illtud.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox saint | name = Saint Illtud | image = St_Illtyd_in_Holy_Trinity_Church,_Abergavenny.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | titles = Illtud Farchog – Illtud the Knight | birth_date = 5th century | birth_place = Wales/England Border (Ewyas, Monmouthshire and Herefordshire | death_date = | death_place = Llanilltud, Brecknockshire Wales | venerated_in = Roman Catholicism; Anglican Communion | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | major_shrine = Llanilltud Fawr, Glamorgan Wales, Loc Ildut, Sizun, Pen-ar-Bed/Finisterre, Brittany | feast_day = 6 November | attributes = | patronage = | issues = | suppressed_date = | suppressed_by = | quote = }}
'''St. Illtud''' (also spelled '''Illtyd''', '''Eltut''', and, in [[Latin]], '''Hildutus'''), also known as '''Illtud Farchog''' "Illtud the Knight", is venerated as the founder-[[abbot]] and teacher of the divinity school known as [[Cor Tewdws]], located in [[Llantwit Major|Llanilltud Fawr]] (Llantwit Major) in the [[Wales|Welsh]] county of [[Glamorgan]]. He founded the monastery and college in the 6th century, and the school is believed to be Britain’s earliest centre of learning.<ref name="Galilee Chapel Project">{{cite web|last=Galilee Chapel Project|title=Home|url=http://www.illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk/|work=Galilee Chapel Project: St. Iltud's Church, Llantwit Major|accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> At its height, it had over 1000 pupils and schooled many of the great saints of the age, including [[Saint David]] of Wales, [[Gildas]] the Historian, and [[Samson of Dol]].<ref name=rudge>Rudge, F.M. (1910). St. Illtyd. In The Catholic Encyclopedia. New York: Robert Appleton Company. Retrieved 1 September 2012</ref>
==Hagiography== St. Illtud was popular among the very ancient Celts, but there are few dependable sources about his life story.<ref name="Saints Alive">{{cite web|last=Father Robert F.|first=McNamara|title=St. Illtud|url=http://kateriirondequoit.org/index.cfm/resources/saints-alive/ignatius-ivo/st-illtud/|work=Saints Alive|publisher=St. Kateri Tekakwitha Parish|accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> The earliest mention of St. Illtud is in the ''Vita Sancti Sampsonis'', written in Dol, Brittany, about 600 AD. According to this account, Illtud was the disciple of Bishop [[Germanus of Auxerre]] in north-central France. According to the St. Sampson biography, Illtud was the most accomplished of all the Britons, and was well versed in the scriptures of the Old and New Testaments, as well as every type of philosophy, including geometry, rhetoric, grammar, and arithmetic.<ref name="St. Illtud"/> He was also "gifted with the power of foretelling future events". It appears that he was an educated Briton living shortly after Rome's departure from the West.<ref name=bowen>[http://wbo.llgc.org.uk/en/s-ILLT-UD0-0475.html Bowen, Emrys George. "Illtud", Welsh Biography Online]</ref>
According to a rather untrustworthy later Norman ''Life of St. Illtud'', c. 1140, Illtud was the son of a Breton prince and a cousin of [[King Arthur]].<ref name="Life of St. Illtud">{{cite web|last=Wade-Evans|first=A. W.|title=The Life of St. Illtud|url=http://www.maryjones.us/ctexts/illtud.html|work=Vitae Sanctorum Britanniae et Genealogiae|publisher=MaryJones.us|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref> According to this ''Life'', Illtud's parents intended him for service in the church and had him educated in literature for this purpose. However, he forsook his religious upbringing, choosing instead to pursue a military career. He took a wife named Trynihid, and became a soldier in western Britain (now Wales), in service first to King Arthur, and then to the King Poulentus. As a result of this, he is sometimes called St. Illtud the Knight. One afternoon, he took a hunting party onto the lands of [[Cadoc]]. The party sent a message to the abbot, demanding that the abbot feed them. The abbot deemed their demand to be very rude and improper, but graciously offered them a meal anyway. Before they could enjoy the meal, the ground opened up and swallowed the whole party as just punishment for their impiety. Only Illtud was spared, and he went to St. Cadog on his knees, begging forgiveness for his sinful act. The abbot told him to give up his selfish ways and go back to his religious upbringing.<ref name="Life of St. Illtud" /> Inspired, Illtud gave up his wife, and became a hermit in the [[Vale of Glamorgan]] (a matrimonial detail which, like many of his alleged miracles, may be regarded as fairly dubious).<ref name="Saints Alive" />
What is certain is that Illtud helped pioneer the monastic life of Wales by founding a monastery in what is now Llantwit Major. This became the first major Welsh monastic school, and was a hub of [[Celtic Christianity]] in [[Sub-Roman Britain]].<ref name="St. Illtud">{{cite web|title=St. Illtud|url=http://www.illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk/britains-earliest-centre-of-learning/saint-illtud/|work=Lent with the Celtic Saints|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>
Illtud's own pupils are reckoned to have included seven sons of British princes and scholars such as Saint Patrick, [[Paul Aurelian]], [[Taliesin]], Gildas and Samson of Dol. Saint David is also believed to have spent some time there.<ref name="Newell1887">{{cite book|last=Newell|first=Ebenezer Josiah|title=A popular history of the ancient British church: with special reference to the church in Wales|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LcnMEvzEEGUC|accessdate=22 January 2012|year=1887|publisher=Society for promoting Christian knowledge}}</ref><ref name="Hall1861">{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Samuel Carter|title=The book of south Wales, the Wye, and the coast|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c_4HAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA252|accessdate=22 January 2012|year=1861|pages=252–}}</ref><ref name="Williams2001">{{cite book|last=Williams|first=Peter N.|title=The Sacred Places of Wales: A Modern Pilgrimage|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PA-0mLsrmMwC&pg=PA21|accessdate=22 January 2012|date=March 2001|publisher=Wales Books|isbn=978-0-7596-0785-9|page=21}}</ref>
==Cult and Veneration== St. Illtud's feast day and commemoration is celebrated on 6 November.,<ref>''Martyrologium Romanum'', 2004, Vatican Press (Typis Vaticanis), page 609.</ref><ref>[http://www.liturgyoffice.org.uk/Calendar/National/Wales1.shtml National Calendar for Wales], accessed 6 February 2012</ref> but the great 'pardon of Ildut at Locildut in Brittany is held on the last Sunday of July. According to legend, Illtud was buried west of the town of [[Brecon]], in the church of Llanilltud (sometimes called Capel Illtud, which was demolished in the late 20th century), on a mountain known as [[Mynydd Illtud]]. Near this church, there is a megalithic monument called ''Bedd Gwyl Illtyd'', or the "Grave of St. Illtud's Eve." Until comparatively recently, Illtud was honoured by the practice of ‘watching’ (keeping vigil) at this stone before his festival.<ref name="Galilee Chapel Project - St. Iltud">{{cite web|title=St. Iltud|url=http://www.illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk/britains-earliest-centre-of-learning/saint-illtud/|work=Galilee Chapel Project|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref>
The ''Life'' tells of Illtyd's bell being recovered from the armies of King [[Edgar the Peaceful]] and of Illtyd's protecting his people against the people of yr [[Hen Ogledd]] in the time of [[William the Conqueror]]. There is also a cross, probably of the ninth century, bearing the inscription: SAMSON POSUIT HANC CRUCEM PRO ANIMA EIUS ILITET SAMSON REGIS SAMUEL ERISAR – "Samson placed his Cross here for his soul, for the soul of Illtud, Samson, Rhain, Sawyl and Ebisar".<ref>[http://www.illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk/britains-earliest-centre-of-learning/the-celtic-crosses/ Galilee Chapel Project. Retrieved 12 Oct 2012]</ref>
There is no formal evidence for a cult of Illtyd surviving from before the 11th century. However, in Celtic countries it is the names of places that tell us most about the existence and veneration of the saints during the oldest times.<ref name="St. Illtud" /> The town of [[Llantwit Major|Llanilltud Fawr]] (Llantwit Major in English) where Illtud's college is located is of course named for him (Welsh: ''llan'' church enclosure + ''Illtud'' + ''mawr'' great. Literally, Illtud's great church),<ref>{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Samuel|title=A Topographical Dictionary of Wales|year=1833}}</ref> and was the chief centre of the cult of St Illtud. In [[Glamorgan]] many churches are dedicated to him, first and foremost [[St Illtyd's Church, Llantwit Major]], which stands on what is believed to have been the site of the monastery. Many other places are dedicated to him is because they belonged to the Llantwit monastery.<ref name="illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk">Llantwit Major site; http://www.illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk/britains-earliest-centre-of-learning/saint-illtud/</ref> Near to Llantwit itself are the villages of [[Llantrithyd]], [[Llantwit Fardre]], and [[Llantrisant]] and at Newcastle and Bridgend churches are dedicated to St Illtud. Brecknockshire north of Glamorgan and the Gower area were two more centres of his cult: the church at Llanhamlach east of Brecon is dedicated to him, and lies south of a Megalithic grave called Ty Illtud, which was a site of mediaeval pilgrimage, the inside walls of the grave bearing incised crosses. The grave is thought to have been a retreat of the saint, as was a similar megalithic monument Roc'h Ildut near Coadut (Coat Ildut/Coed Illtud/ Illtud's Wood) in Brittany, sadly demolished in the 19th century. Llantrisant's three saints were Illtud, Gwynno and Tyfodwg. In Merthyr Tudful there are holy wells of Gwynno and Illtud. West of Brecon, the church of Llanilltud is on a mountain known as [[Mynydd Illtud]]. Dedications in and around Gower include Ilston, formerly Llanilltud Gwyr, Oxwich, a holy well of S. Iltut in Llanrhidian, Llanilltud Fach, or Llantwit-juxta-Neath and Pen-bre, Carmarthenshire. A 13th century church on [[Caldey Island]], [[Pembrokeshire]], is dedicated to the saint. In north Wales there is a [[Llanelltyd]] near Dolgellau. There are no dedications to St Illtud in Cornwall but many in Brittany (approximately 24 if other place-names like Aberildut are included) though they are largely confined to the ancient dioceses of Leon, Treguier and Vannes, with small outliers in the region of Saint Malo, originally in the diocese of his pupil Samson.<ref name="illtudsgalileechapel.org.uk"/>
John Stowe's 1603 list of the bishops of London includes an "Iltuta"<ref name=stowe>{{cite book|last=Stowe|first=John|authorlink=John Stowe|title=The Annales of England|p=C3|url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsofenglandt00stow#page/n61/mode/2up/|date=1605|publisher=G. Bishop & T. Adams|location=London}}</ref> who is sometimes conflated with Illtud.<ref name=pseudodennis>Parker, John. [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/dionysius/works.iii.iv.i.html ''The Works of Dionysius the Areopagite, Now First Translated into English, From the Original Greek'', Appendix: "List of Bishops".] James Parker& Co. (London), 1897.</ref>
==Arthurian Connections== According to the 12th century ''Life of St. Illtud'', Illtud's father was Bicanus, a minor Breton prince, and his mother was Rieingulid, a princess and daughter of [[Amlawdd Wledig|Anblaud]], king of Lesser Britannia (Brittany). This is probably meant to be Ewyas, an area on the Herefordshire-Monmouthshire border, which retains many memories of Arthur and Illtud's family. He was alleged to be the cousin of the legendary King Arthur, serving him as a young soldier.
One medieval Welsh document names Illtud, in his knightly days, as one of the triumvirate (the others were named Cadoc and Peredur) to whom King Arthur gave custody of the [[Holy Grail]]. On this basis, some scholars have tried to identify Knight Illtud with Sir [[Galahad]].<ref name="Saints Alive" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://www.maryjones.us/ctexts/illtud.html |title=The Life of St. Illtud |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171112031710/http://www.maryjones.us/ctexts/illtud.html |archivedate=12 November 2017 }} *{{la icon}} {{cite web |url=http://jrider.web.wesleyan.edu/wescourses/2001f/fren234/01/lifeofstilltudlatin.htm |title=The Life of St. Illtud |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908062131/http://jrider.web.wesleyan.edu/wescourses/2001f/fren234/01/lifeofstilltudlatin.htm |archivedate=8 September 2011 }}
{{authority control}}

{{Infobox FBI Ten Most Wanted | name = Jason Derek Brown | image = Age accelerated image of Jason Derek Brown.jpg | image_size = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|7|1}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]] | birth_name = | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | alias = Derek Brown
Greg Johnson
Harline Johnson
Greg Harline Johnson
John Brown
Jay Brown | charge = *[[Unlawful Flight to Avoid Prosecution]] * [[First degree murder]] * [[Armed robbery]] |reward = $200,000 | conviction = | conviction_penalty = | occupation = Ring salesman, toy salesman, golf equipment importer | parents = | siblings = | spouse = | children = | added_date = December 8, 2007 | caught_date = | remove_date = | number = 489 | status = Currently on the FBI's top ten most wanted list |Status choices: Caught Dead Removed |No status or other status defaults to currently on list }} '''Jason Derek Brown''' (born July 1, 1969) is an [[United States|American]] [[fugitive]] wanted for [[first degree murder]] and armed [[robbery]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Arizona]] on November 29, 2004.{{cite web |first=Emily |last=Bittner |url=http://www.azcentral.com/community/ahwatukee/articles/1130armoredcar30.html |title=Armored-car guard shot, killed |publisher=''The Arizona Republic'' |date=November 30, 2004 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} On December 8, 2007 he was named by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] as the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives, 2000s|489th fugitive to be placed]] on the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives|Ten Most Wanted list]]. Brown is considered armed and extremely dangerous.{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/jason-derek-brown/%40%40poster.pdf |title=FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitive poster |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-08-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021191133/http://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/jason-derek-brown/%40%40poster.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-21 |df= }} ==Biography== Brown was born in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] in 1969 to David John Brown, Sr.{{cite web |first=Robert Craig |last=Harman |url=http://www.mission.net/france/paris/news.php?nID=2566 |title=New Details in the Jason Derek Brown Case |publisher=France Paris Mission |date=April 23, 2005 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }}{{cite web |first=Lindsey |last=Collom |url=http://www.azcentral.com/specials/special14/articles/1028coldcase28.html |title=FBI looking for suspect in fatal heist |publisher=''The Arizona Republic'' |date=October 28, 2005 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} He attended [[Laguna Beach High School]].{{cite web |first=Sarah |last=Muensch |url=http://www.azcentral.com/specials/special14/articles/1124coldcase1124.html |title=Slayer of armored-car guard still free |publisher=''The Arizona Republic'' |date=November 24, 2006 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} Brown speaks fluent [[French language|French]] and has a [[master's degree]] in [[international business]]. Brown served a mission for [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] in [[Paris]] from 1988 to 1990. Between 1990 and 2004, he resided in several places in [[Orange County, California|Orange County]], California, including [[Dana Point, California|Dana Point]] and the [[Corona del Mar, Newport Beach, California|Corona del Mar]] neighborhood of [[Newport Beach, California|Newport Beach]]. Brown owned two businesses based in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], Toys Unlimited and On The Doorstep Advertising, both of which were operated out of his Utah home.{{cite web |first=Emily |last=Bittner |url=http://www.azcentral.com/community/ahwatukee/articles/1207armoredcar07.html |title=Murder suspect named in killing of armored car guard |publisher=''The Arizona Republic'' |date=December 7, 2004 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} Brown had been employed as a toy salesman and [[golf equipment]] importer{{cite web |title=Suspect In Phoenix Death Hits Most Wanted List |url=http://ktar.com/?sid=668578&nid=6 |publisher=[[KPHO-TV]] |date=December 10, 2007 |accessdate=May 22, 2013 }} to support his luxurious lifestyle and expensive tastes, such as cars, motorbikes and boats.{{cite web |first=Melissa |last=Underwood |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,329367,00.html |title=Wanted for the Murder of an Armored Car Guard: Jason Derek Brown |publisher=''Fox News'' |date=February 7, 2008 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} Brown portrayed himself as a [[wealth]]y man, despite the fact he had [[Default (finance)|default]]ed on at least one large loan and was racking up tens of thousands of dollars of debt in 2004. In November 2004, Brown took a firearms class. He bought a .45-caliber [[Glock pistol]] days before the class at Totally Awesome Guns & Range in Salt Lake City. Brown passed a [[background check]], and as part of the class, was [[fingerprint]]ed and his prints were sent to state and federal authorities. Brown's instructor, Clark Aposhian, described him as "an obnoxious student" who was inexperienced with firearms. Brown accidentally fired a round into a truck during a practice shooting. He paid approximately $1,300 in damages to the car owner.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/KNTV_20130805_050000_Dateline_NBC|title=Dateline NBC : KNTV : August 4, 2013 10:00pm-11:01pm PDT : Free Streaming : Internet Archive|work=Internet Archive}} At this time, Brown was living in an [[Ahwatukee, Phoenix, Arizona|Ahwatukee]], [[Arizona]] hotel near an [[AMC Theatres|AMC movie theater]].{{cite web |first=Lindsey |last=Collom |url=http://www.azcentral.com/community/ahwatukee/articles/1210ar-armored10Z14.html |title=Slaying suspect's been seen |publisher=''The Arizona Republic'' |date=December 10, 2004 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} He was captured on surveillance tape having a conversation with another man in the hotel lobby. The man is considered to be a possible accomplice or witness; however, his identity remains unknown. ==Robbery and murder== On November 29, 2004, Robert Keith Palomares, a 24-year-old [[armored truck]] guard, was carrying the weekend deposits outside the AMC theater at 4915 E. Ray Road in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]. At approximately 10 a.m., a hooded gunman ambushed and shot Palomares with a .45-caliber semiautomatic Glock. Five out of six bullets fired struck him in the head. Palomares was armed, but did not have time to defend himself. The gunman took a bag of money containing $56,000 in cash, fled into a nearby alley and left on a bicycle. Palomares was transported to Good Samaritan Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Witnesses initially described the shooter as a 25- to 30-year-old [[Hispanic]] man. Authorities recovered the bicycle and fingerprints, and instead subsequently linked the [[Caucasian race|caucasian]] Brown to the murder. He was soon considered a prime suspect in the case{{cite web |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=DSNB&d_place=DSNB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=106DD82866B5DA23&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D |title=Suspect in slaying has Utah ties |publisher=''[[The Deseret News]]'' |date=December 8, 2004 |format=Fee required |accessdate=July 27, 2009 }} and an [[arrest warrant]] was issued on December 4 by [[Maricopa County]] Superior Court charging Brown with [[first degree murder]] and [[armed robbery]]. Brown was also charged with unlawful flight to avoid prosecution in a federal arrest warrant issued on December 6 by the [[United States District Court for the District of Arizona]].{{cite web |url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/local/articles/1211mostwanted1211.html |title=Suspect in Phoenix murder now among FBI Most Wanted |publisher=''Associated Press'' |date=December 11, 2007 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} Investigators have considered that a possible motive for Brown to commit these crimes could have been his desperate financial situation. ==Fugitive== After Brown was identified as a suspect, he fled from Arizona to [[Henderson, Nevada|Henderson]], [[Nevada]]. Brown traveled to [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] and swapped his [[BMW]] for a black [[Cadillac Escalade]] he had in storage. He traveled to Orange County, California, staying there with relatives until December 6, 2004, when [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agents carrying out an arrest warrant missed him by two hours. Brown used his credit card at a gas station in [[South Orange County]], went to [[San Diego]] near the [[Mexican border]], and then traveled to [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]]. After this, FBI stated that Brown became a "ghost" and went completely [[off-the-grid]]. On January 16, 2005, authorities found Brown's Cadillac in a long-term parking lot at [[Portland International Airport]]. While in Portland, Brown mailed a package containing clothes and golf equipment to his brother David John Brown II in San Diego. On April 20, 2005, David Brown was [[indictment|indicted]] for [[obstruction of justice]]. The indictment claimed he tampered with evidence when he cleaned out Jason's BMW in early December after driving it from a Las Vegas storage facility to California. By 2005, the FBI had more than 200 leads in the case. The majority of leads were outside Arizona and dozens were outside the [[United States]], including possible sightings in Canada. Due to his "[[Surf culture|California surfer dude]]" appearance and his ability to blend into crowds, the FBI has had more leads on Brown than anyone else on the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives|Ten Most Wanted list]], with most of the leads unhelpful. Reporters have noted he bears a close resemblance to actor [[Sean Penn]], and one of Penn's [[body double]]s was once mistakenly arrested by authorities who thought he was Brown.{{cite news |title=FBI's Most Wanted fugitive 'could be hiding among Mormon community' after EIGHT. YEARS on the run |author=Louise Boyle |work=Daily Mail |date=November 26, 2012 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2238819/Most-Wanted-fugitive-Jason-Derek-Brown-hiding-Mormon-community.html#ixzz2DYk3xQPB |accessdate=November 28, 2012}} Authorities believe that he may be hiding among the Mormon community under an assumed identity, living with a woman who may not know his real identity, or that he has fled the country and could be living in [[France]] or [[Thailand]].{{cite web|author=The Nation April 4, 2013 1:00 am |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/Tarit-Thailand-is-regions-No-1-terror-target-30203344.html |title=Tarit: Thailand is region's No 1 terror target - The Nation |publisher=Nationmultimedia.com |date=2013-04-04 |accessdate=2013-08-07}} On December 8, 2007, Brown was named by the FBI as the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives, 2000s|489th fugitive to be placed]] on their Ten Most Wanted list. The FBI is offering a reward of up to $200,000 for information leading to his capture (the reward was doubled on March 25, 2013).{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/phoenix/press-releases/2013/fbi-announces-increased-reward-for-ten-most-wanted-fugitive-jason-derek-brown|title=FBI announces increased reward for ten most wanted fugitive Jason Derek Brown |publisher=Fbi.gov |accessdate=13 June 2013}} The most recent confirmed sighting was in August 2008, when an acquaintance of Brown recognized him while they were stopped at a [[traffic light]] near [[Hogle Zoo]] in Salt Lake City. Their mutual recognition prompted Brown to drive through the stoplight. The witness informed authorities of the sighting.{{cite web |first=Ben |last=Winslow |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700259183/FBI-fugitive-may-be-living-high-life-in-SL.html |title=FBI fugitive may be living high life in S.L. |publisher=''Deseret News'' |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} According to him, Brown had longer hair and a deeper tan than in the 2004 photograph of his wanted poster.{{cite web |first=Lindsey |last=Collom |url=http://www.azcentral.com/community/ahwatukee/articles/2008/09/16/20080916arizfugitive.html |title=Ariz. fugitive reportedly seen in Salt Lake City |publisher=''The Arizona Republic'' |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} ==See also== * [[List of fugitives from justice who disappeared]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111012083057/http://www.amw.com/fugitives/brief.cfm?id=29538 Brown's profile on ''America's Most Wanted''] {{FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives by year}} *[https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/jason-derek-brown Jason Derek Brown's FBI Top 10 Most Wanted Fugitive Alert] {{DEFAULTSORT:Brown, Jason Derek}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:2000s missing person cases]] [[Category:2004 murders in the United States]] [[Category:20th-century Mormon missionaries]] [[Category:American bank robbers]] [[Category:American Mormon missionaries in France]] [[Category:American salespeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Utah]] [[Category:Criminals of Phoenix, Arizona]] [[Category:FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted on murder charges]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted on robbery charges]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles]] [[Category:People from Newport Beach, California]] [[Category:People from Salt Lake City]] [[Category:Living people]]

[[Colonel]] '''John Blennerhassett''' (1691 – 5 May 1775) was an [[Anglo-Irish]] politician who represented two constituencies in the [[Irish House of Commons]] between 1709 and 1775.Sir Bernard Burke, ''A genealogical and heraldic history of the landed gentry of Ireland'' (1899), 48. Blennerhassett was born in [[County Kerry]], the eldest son of [[John Blennerhassett (died 1709)|John Blennerhassett]] and Margaret Crosbie. He served in the Kerry Militia and was a colonel by 1756. He was first elected as a Member of Parliament in 1709, taking his father's seat representing [[Kerry (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|County Kerry]].ThePeerage.com (entry #279655) http://thepeerage.com/p27966.htm#i279655 Between 1713 and 1715, he was MP for [[Tralee (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Tralee]]. He was again returned as the MP for Kerry in 1715, serving until 1727. He served as [[High Sheriff of Kerry]] in 1717. Between 1727 and 1760, he served as the MP for Tralee, before serving as MP for Kerry for a third period between 1761 and his death in 1775. He was [[Father of the House|Father of the Irish House of Commons]]. He married Jane Denny, with whom he had two sons, [[John Blennerhassett (1715–1763)|John]] and [[Arthur Blennerhassett (1719–1799)|Arthur]], and four daughters.ThePeerage.com (entry #279655) http://thepeerage.com/p27966.htm#i279655 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|ie}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Kerry (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Kerry]] | with = [[Edward Denny (1676–1727)|Edward Denny]] | years = 1709–1713 | before = [[Edward Denny (1676–1727)|Edward Denny]]
[[John Blennerhassett (died 1709)|John Blennerhassett]] | after = [[Edward Denny (1676–1727)|Edward Denny]]
[[Maurice Crosbie, 1st Baron Brandon|Sir Maurice Crosbie]] }} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Tralee (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Tralee]] | with = [[Samuel Morris (Irish MP, 1695–1723)|Samuel Morris]] | years = 1713–1715 | before = [[Samuel Morris (Irish MP, 1695–1723)|Samuel Morris]]
[[Arthur Hyde (politician)|Arthur Hyde]] | after = [[Samuel Morris (Irish MP, 1695–1723)|Samuel Morris]]
[[Robert Taylor (Irish politician)|Robert Taylor]] }} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Kerry (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Kerry]] | with = [[Maurice Crosbie, 1st Baron Brandon|Sir Maurice Crosbie]] | years = 1715–1727 | before = [[Edward Denny (1676–1727)|Edward Denny]]
[[Maurice Crosbie, 1st Baron Brandon|Sir Maurice Crosbie]] | after = [[Arthur Denny (politician)|Arthur Denny]]
[[Maurice Crosbie, 1st Baron Brandon|Sir Maurice Crosbie]] }} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Tralee (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Tralee]] | with = [[Arthur Blennerhassett (1687–1758)|Arthur Blennerhassett]] (1727–1743) | with2 = [[Arthur Blennerhassett (1719–1799)|Arthur Blennerhassett]] (1743–1760) | years = 1727–1760 | before = [[Luke Gardiner]]
[[William Sprigge]] | after = [[Rowland Bateman]]
[[Edward Herbert (Irish politician)|Edward Herbert]] }} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Kerry (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Kerry]] | with = [[William Petty, 2nd Earl of Shelburne|Viscount FitzMaurice]] | with2 = [[John Blennerhassett (1761–1762)|John Blennerhassett]] (1762–1763) | with3 = [[Thomas FitzMaurice (Irish MP)|Thomas FitzMaurice]] (1763–1768) | with4 = [[Sir Barry Denny, 1st Baronet|Barry Denny]] (1768–1775) | years = 1761–1775 | before = [[John Blennerhassett (1715–1763)|John Blennerhassett]]
[[Lancelot Crosbie]] | after = [[Sir Barry Denny, 1st Baronet|Barry Denny]]
[[Arthur Blennerhassett (1719–1799)|Arthur Blennerhassett]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blennerhassett, John}} [[Category:1691 births]] [[Category:1775 deaths]] [[Category:Irish MPs 1703–13]] [[Category:Irish MPs 1713–14]] [[Category:Irish MPs 1715–27]] [[Category:Irish MPs 1727–60]] [[Category:Irish MPs 1761–68]] [[Category:Irish MPs 1769–76]] [[Category:18th-century Irish people]] [[Category:People from County Kerry]] [[Category:Anglo-Irish people]] [[Category:High Sheriffs of Kerry]] [[Category:Blennerhassett family]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Ireland (pre-1801) for County Kerry constituencies]]

{{short description|American firearms designer}} {{Other people}} {{refimprove|date = March 2017}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = John Moses Browning | honorific_suffix = [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|BOL]] | image = JOHN M. BROWNING.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Browning, c. 1915 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1855|01|23}} | birth_place = [[Ogden, Utah|Ogden]], [[Utah Territory]] | baptised = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1926|11|26|1855|01|23}} | death_place = [[Liège]], Belgium | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | burial_place = | burial_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Gunsmith, founder of [[Browning Arms Company]] | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | denomination = | spouse = Rachel Therese Child Browning | children = 10, including [[Val A. Browning]] | parents = | mother = Elizabeth Caroline Clark | father = [[Jonathan Browning (inventor)|Jonathan Browning]] | relatives = | awards = [[The Franklin Institute Awards|John Scott Medal]] (1905)
[[Order of Léopold]] (1914) | website = | signature = John M. Browning signature.png | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''John Moses Browning''' (January 23, 1855{{cite web |last=Pelley |first=Doug |url=http://www.dapcom.com/Temples/Headstones/browning.htm |title=Pictures of Headstones: John M. Browning |date=July 2004 |access-date=23 January 2007 |work=Dapcom}} – November 26, 1926) was an American [[firearm]]s designer who developed many varieties of military and civilian firearms, [[Cartridge (firearms)|cartridges]], and gun mechanisms{{snd}} many of which are still in use around the world.{{cite book |last=Borth |first=Christy |title=Masters of Mass Production |pages=152, 156-9 |publisher=[[Bobbs-Merrill Company]] |location=Indianapolis |year=1945 |oclc=609185692 |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=eq9BAAAAIAAJ}} He made his first firearm at age 10 in his father's gun shop, and was awarded the first of his 128 firearm patents on October 7, 1879, at the age of 24.{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9016723/John-Moses-Browning |title=John Moses Browning |first=Richard C. |last=Rattenbury |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.]] |access-date=22 September 2018}} He is regarded as one of the most successful firearms designers of the 19th and 20th centuries, and pioneered the development of modern [[Automatic firearm|automatic]] and [[semi-automatic firearm]]s.{{cite web |quote=By 1900, over 75% of the repeating sporting arms on the United States market, both lever and pump, were of John's invention |url=http://files.asme.org/ASMEORG/Communities/History/Landmarks/5508.pdf |title=Browning Firearms Collection |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120215642/http://files.asme.org/ASMEORG/Communities/History/Landmarks/5508.pdf |archive-date=20 November 2012 |work=[[The American Society of Mechanical Engineers]] |date=18 November 1989}} Browning influenced nearly all categories of firearms design. He invented, or made significant improvements to, single-shot, [[lever-action]], and [[Pump-action|pump-action]] rifles and shotguns. Arguably, his most significant contributions were in the area of autoloading firearms. He developed the first reliable and compact [[semi-automatic pistol|autoloading pistol]]s by inventing the [[telescoping bolt]], then integrating the bolt and [[barrel shroud]] into what is known as the [[pistol slide]]. Browning's telescoping bolt design is now found on nearly every modern [[semi-automatic pistol]], as well as several modern [[Automatic firearm|fully automatic]] weapons. He also developed the first [[Gas operation|gas-operated]] firearm, the [[M1895 Colt–Browning machine gun|Colt–Browning Model 1895]] [[machine gun]]{{snd}} a system that surpassed mechanical [[recoil operation]] to become the standard for most high-power self-loading firearm designs worldwide. He also made significant contributions to [[automatic cannon]] development. Browning's most successful designs include the [[M1911 pistol]], the [[Browning Hi Power]] pistol, the water-cooled [[M1917 Browning machine gun|M1917]], the air-cooled [[M1919 Browning machine gun|M1919]], and [[heavy machine gun|heavy]] [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2]] machine guns, the [[M1918 Browning Automatic Rifle|Browning Automatic Rifle]], and the [[Browning Auto-5]]{{snd}} the first [[semi-automatic shotgun]]. Some of these arms are still manufactured, often with only minor changes in detail and cosmetics to those assembled by Browning or his licensees. His guns are some of the most copied firearms in the world. == Life and works == His father [[Jonathan Browning (inventor)|Jonathan Browning]], who was among the thousands of [[Mormon]] [[settler|pioneer]]s in the mass exodus from [[Nauvoo, Illinois]] to [[Utah]], established a [[gunsmith]] shop in Ogden in 1852. As was common in the Mormon community at that time, Jonathan Browning was a [[polygamy|polygamist]], having taken three wives. He fathered 19 children, including John Moses Browning with his wife Elizabeth Caroline Clark.[https://www.browning.com/news/articles/honor-father-of-the-father-of-modern-firearms.html Browning.com] "In Honor of the Parents of "the Father of Modern Firearms." Retrieved September 5, 2018. John Moses worked in his father's Ogden shop from the age of seven, where he was taught basic engineering and manufacturing principles, and encouraged to experiment with new concepts. He developed his first rifle, a [[single-shot]] [[falling block action]] design, then, in 1878, in partnership with his younger brother, co-founded John Moses and Matthew Sandifer Browning Company, later renamed [[Browning Arms Company]], and began to produce this and other non-military firearms. Like his father, Browning was a Mormon, and served a two-year [[mission (LDS Church)]] in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] beginning on March 28, 1887.{{cite web|title=Early Mormon Missionaries: John Moses Browning|url=https://history.lds.org/missionary/individual/john-moses-browning-1855?lang=eng}} He married Rachel Theresa Child (14 Sep 1860 – 30 Sep 1934) on April 10, 1879 at Ogden, Weber, Utah, and the couple had 10 children, two of whom died in infancy.[https://www.browning.com/news/articles/happy-father-s-day-john-moses-browning.html Browning] "Honoring 'The Father of the Browning Company.'", Browning.com. Retrieved September 22, 2018. === Arms === Production examples of the [[Winchester Model 1885 Single Shot Rifle|Model 1885 Single Shot Rifle]] caught the attention of the [[Winchester Repeating Arms Company]], who dispatched a representative to evaluate the competition. Winchester bought the design for $8,000 and moved production to their [[Connecticut]] factory. From 1883, Browning worked in partnership with Winchester and designed a series of rifles and shotguns, most notably the lever action [[Winchester Model 1887/1901|Winchester Model 1887]] and the [[Winchester Model 1897|Model 1897]] pump shotgun, the falling-block single-shot [[Winchester Model 1885|Model 1885]], and the lever-action [[Winchester Model 1886|Model 1886]], [[Winchester Model 1892|Model 1892]], [[Winchester Model 1894|Model 1894]], [[Winchester Model 1895|Model 1895]] rifles as well as the [[long recoil]] operated semi-automatic [[Remington Model 8]] rifle, many of which are still in production today in some form; over six million Model 1894s had been produced as of 1983, more than any other sporting rifle in history.Wallack, LR. "Sixty Million Guns". 1983. In ''Gun Digest Treasury'', Harold A. Murtz, editor, DBI Books. 1994 p.190 {{ISBN|0873491564}} Winchester manufactured several popular small arms designed by John M. Browning. For decades in the late 19th Century-early 20th Century, Browning designs and Winchester firearms were synonymous and the collaboration was highly successful. This came to an end when Browning proposed a new [[long recoil]] operated semi-automatic shotgun design, a prototype finished in 1898, to Winchester management, which ultimately became the Browning Auto-5 shotgun. As was the custom of the time, Browning's earlier designs had been licensed exclusively to Winchester (and other manufacturers) for a single fee payment. With this new product, Browning introduced in his negotiations a continuous royalty fee based upon unit sales, rather than a single front-end fee payment. If the new shotgun became highly successful, Browning stood to make substantially more fee income over the prior license fee arrangements. Winchester management was displeased with the bold change in their relationship, and rejected Browning's offer. Remington Arms was also approached, however the president of Remington died of a heart attack as Browning waited to offer them the gun. This forced Browning to look overseas to produce the shotgun. However; Remington would later produce a copy of the Auto-5 as the Model 11 which was used by the US Military and was also sold to the civilian market. Having recently successfully negotiated firearm licenses with [[Fabrique Nationale de Herstal]] of Belgium (FN), Browning took the new shotgun design to FN; the offer was accepted and FN manufactured the new shotgun, honoring its inventor, as the Browning Auto-5. The Browning Auto-5 was continuously manufactured as a highly popular shotgun throughout the 20th century. In response, Winchester shifted reliance away from John Browning designs when it adopted a shotgun design of Thomas Crossley Johnson for the new Winchester Model 1911 SL, (Johnson had to work around Browning's patents of what became the Auto-5) and the new Model 1912 pump shotgun, which was based in small part upon design features of the earlier Browning-designed Winchester Model 1897 shotgun. This shift marked the end of an era of Winchester-Browning collaboration. === Later work and life === [[File:JohnBrowning.jpeg|thumb|upright|Browning in his later years]] John Browning was known as a dedicated and tireless innovator and experimenter who sought breakthrough consumer-oriented features and performance and reliability improvements in small arms designs. He did not retire from his career in his later years, but dedicated his entire adult life{{snd}} literally to his last day{{snd}} to these pursuits. On November 26, 1926, while working at the bench on a self-loading pistol design for [[Fabrique Nationale de Herstal]] (FN) in [[Liège (city)|Liège]], he died of heart failure in the design shop of his son [[Val A. Browning]]. Even the 9 mm semi-automatic pistol he was working on when he died had great design merit and was eventually completed in 1935, by Belgian designer [[Dieudonne Saive]]. Released as the Fabrique Nationale GP35, it was more popularly known as the successful [[Browning Hi-Power]] pistol, a favorite of sportsmen, gun collectors as well as many military and law enforcement agencies around the world. The premium priced [[Browning Superposed]] shotgun, an over-under shotgun design, was his last completed firearm design and possibly his most elegant. It was marketed originally with twin triggers; a single trigger modification was later completed by his son, Val Browning. Commercially introduced in 1931 by FN, [[Browning Superposed]] shotguns, and their more affordable cousins, the [[Browning Citori]] made in Asia, continue to be manufactured into the 21st century, and come with varying grades of fine hand engraving and premium quality wood. Throughout his life, Browning designed a vast array of military and civilian small arms for his own company, as well as for [[Winchester Repeating Arms Company|Winchester]], [[Colt's Manufacturing Company|Colt]], [[Remington Arms|Remington]], [[Savage Arms|Savage]], [[Stevens Arms|Stevens]], and [[Fabrique Nationale de Herstal]] of Belgium. Browning firearms have been made, both licensed and unlicensed, by hundreds of factories around the world. [[Browning Arms Company]] was established in 1927, the year after Browning's death. In 1977, FN Herstal acquired the company. === Legacy === The [[M1895 Colt–Browning machine gun|M1895 Machine Gun]] saw action in the Spanish–American War with the United States Marines. The [[M1911 pistol|Colt M1911]], [[M1919 Browning machine gun|Browning 1917/19]], and the [[M1918 Browning Automatic Rifle|BAR]] saw action with US forces in [[World War I]], [[World War II]] and the [[Korean War]], with the M1911 going on to serve as the U.S.'s standard military [[side arm]] until 1985; a [[MEU(SOC) pistol|variant]] is still used by [[Marine Expeditionary Unit|special operations units of the United States Marine Corps]] and the design remains very popular amongst civilian shooters and some police departments. The [[Browning Hi-Power]] has a similarly lengthy period of service outside the United States, and remains the standard side arm of the Australian and Canadian armed forces. The [[M2 Browning machine gun]], the timeless .50 caliber "Ma Deuce", which was developed in 1918, entered service with the US Armed Forces in 1921, and remains in active service for nearly a century with armed forces across the world in a variety of roles. The [[M4 cannon]], a 37mm [[autocannon]], was initially designed by Browning in 1921, and entered service in 1938; it was used both in aircraft and on the [[U.S. Navy]] [[PT boat]] during World War II. == Products == Several of Browning's designs are still in production today. Some of his most notable designs include: === Cartridges === {{div col}} *[[.25 ACP]] *[[.32 ACP]] *[[.38 ACP]] *[[.380 ACP]] *[[.45 ACP]] *[[.50 BMG]] *[[9mm Browning Long]] {{div col end}} === ACP]]) *[[FN Model 1903]] ([[9mm Browning Long]]) *[[Colt Model 1903 Pocket Hammerless]] ([[.32 ACP]]) *[[FN Model 1906 Vest Pocket]] ([[.25 ACP]]) *[[Colt Model 1908 Vest Pocket]] ([[.25 ACP]]) Automatic Rifle|U.S. M1918 Browning Automatic Rifle]] (BAR) *[[M2 Browning machine gun|U.S. M2]] [[.50 BMG|.50]]-caliber heavy machine gun *[[M4 cannon|U.S. M4]] 37mm Automatic Gun == Selected patents
