revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=February 2017}} {{overly detailed|date=February 2017}} }} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = John R. Crane |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |education = [[Northwestern University]]
[[Georgetown University]] |occupation = Pentagon executive, consultant |employer = U.S. Congress
[[Office of the Inspector General, U.S. Department of Defense|Defense Dept Inspector General]]
[[Government Accountability Project]] |organization = |known_for = Support for government whistleblowers |notable_works = |awards = [[Joe A. Callaway Award for Civic Courage]] |relatives = [[Günther Rüdel]] (grandfather) |website = |signature = |signature_size = |signature_alt = |footnotes = }} '''John Crane''' is a former [[Office of the Inspector General, U.S. Department of Defense|Assistant Inspector General of the U.S. Department of Defense]] known for his advocacy on behalf of government [[whistleblowing|whistleblowers]]. He was fired in 2013 and now works for the [[Government Accountability Project]], a [[non-governmental organization|non-governmental]] whistleblower support organization. ==Career== Crane graduated from [[Northwestern University]] with a bachelor's degree in [[Asian studies]] in 1980. He then studied at the Arabic Language Unit of the [[American University in Cairo]] from 1980-82.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Crane worked as press secretary for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[United States House of Representatives|Congressman]] [[William Louis Dickinson|Bill Dickinson]], ranking member on the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|House Armed Services Committee]], from 1985-87. Dickinson advocated establishing an Office of the Inspector General in the [[United States Department of Defense|Defense Department]].{{cite web |last=Hertsgaard |first=Mark |author2=Felix Kasten |author3=Marcel Rosenbach |author4=Holger Stark |title=Blowing the Whistle: Former US Official Reveals Risks Faced by Internal Critics |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/ex-us-official-reveals-risks-faced-by-internal-govt-critics-a-1093360-2.html |work=Spiegel Online International |date=May 22, 2016}}, a translation of the German article in ''Der Spiegel'' No. 21/2016 (May 21, 2016). When that office was created in 1982, Crane became one of its first employees, helping to set up the [[hotline]]s for whistleblowers to report waste, fraud, or abuse. He had the text of the [[Whistleblower Protection Act]] of 1989 printed up as pamphlets for the personnel in the IG's office to refer to in carrying out their responsibilities. Crane's work also included crafting committee press releases involving analysis of the [[National Defense Authorization Act]] and consequences for national defense policy.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} In 1987, Crane became Legislative Director and Press Secretary for [[Silicon Valley]] Congressman [[Ernie Konnyu]], where he did supervisory work on formulating legislative policy agenda and communications thereof.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} By 1988, Crane moved to the Defense Department's Inspector General office as a Congressional Liaison. He represented the IG on congressional activities and legislation as well as in contacts on legislative and public affairs with the [[Office of the Secretary of Defense]]. In 1994 Crane was promoted to Director of the Office of Communication in the IG. He managed public affairs efforts including public statements and congressional testimonies regarding US activities in [[Southwest Asia]]. He was promoted to a high-level executive position, the Assistant Inspector General for Communications, in 2004. He administered change management and communication policy for Europe, Southwest Asia, and [[East Asia]]. He also performed strategic planning and was Principal Advisor to the IG. He was responsible for whistleblowing and transparency, including strategic (internal) and public affairs communications that included responses regarding the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information]] (FOIA) and [[Privacy Act of 1974|Privacy Act]]s. Crane reviewed legislation and advised on legislative changes. He was fired from his post as an assistant inspector general in February 2013, an action he claims came in response to his advocacy on behalf of whistleblowers who faced illegal reprisal from his superiors in the IG and from other areas of the [[Federal government of the United States#Executive branch|executive branch]].{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} In October 2013, Crane joined the Government Accountability Project (GAP) as a consultant on legislative impact analysis. At GAP, he works with whistleblowers related to [[national security]] and on legislative, FOIA, and Privacy Act impacts.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Crane earned an Executive Master's in leadership from [[Georgetown University]] in 2015.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} ===Whistleblower program official becomes whistleblower=== [[Edward Snowden]] went to the press with revelations about the NSA due to the experience of previous whistleblowers, such as [[Thomas Andrews Drake]], [[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]], [[J. Kirk Wiebe]], [[Ed Loomis]], and [[Diane Roark]], who initially reported their concerns within the system and faced intense retaliation.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} After making his concerns about mistreatment of whistleblowers known to his superiors, Crane was removed from his position in 2013. He was a recipient of the 2015 [[Joe A. Callaway Award for Civic Courage]].{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} He is a major focus of [[investigative journalism|investigative journalist]] [[Mark Hertsgaard]]'s book, ''Bravehearts: Whistle-blowing in the Age of Snowden''.{{cite book |last = Hertsgaard |first = Mark |author-link = Mark Hertsgaard |title = Bravehearts: Whistle-blowing in the Age of Snowden |publisher = Hot Books |date = 2016 |location = New York |isbn = 978-1510703377 }} ==See also== * [[Whistleblower protection in the United States]] ** [[Defense Intelligence Community Whistleblower Protection]] * [[List of whistleblowers]] ** [[Global surveillance whistleblowers]] ** [[Thomas Tamm]] ** [[Russ Tice]] ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite news |last = Clark |first = Charles S. |title = Fired Pentagon Whistleblower Goes Public in Attack on IG's Office |newspaper = Government Executive |date = May 23, 2016 |url = http://www.govexec.com/defense/2016/05/fired-pentagon-whistleblower-goes-public-attack-igs-office/128511/ |access-date = May 23, 2016}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=8181512}} * [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/22/snowden-whistleblower-protections-john-crane Snowden calls for whistleblower shield after claims by new Pentagon source] (Spencer Ackerman and Ewen MacAskill, ''The Guardian'') * [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/23/national-security-whistleblowing-inquiry-edward-snowden-analysis Future of national security whistleblowing at stake in US inquiry] (Ewen MacAskill and Spencer Ackerman, ''The Guardian'') {{DEFAULTSORT:Crane, John}} [[Category:United States Department of Defense officials]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:Northwestern University alumni]] [[Category:Georgetown University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.comment: /* Apparition to Juan Bernardino */
revision.text:
'''Juan Diego Bernardino''' (ca. 1456 – May 15, 1544) was one of two [[Aztec]] peasants alleged to have had visions of the [[Blessed Virgin Mary|Virgin Mary]] as [[Our Lady of Guadalupe]] in 1531.
== Life == Little is known of the life of Juan Bernardino. He lived in [[Tolpetlac]], some nine miles north of [[Tenochtitlán]] and brought up his nephew, Saint [[Juan Diego Cuauhtlatoatzin|Juan Diego]], after the latter's parents died. After the 1529 death of Juan Diego's wife, Maria Lucia, Juan Diego moved to be near his then-aged uncle in Tolpet.
== Vision of Our Lady == At the time of the [[Marian apparition|apparitions]] of the [[Blessed Virgin Mary]] to [[Juan Diego]] in December 1531, Juan Bernardino fell ill. According to most sources, he contracted ''[[cocolixtle]]'', a dreaded fever that normally led to death. On December 9, 1531, Juan Diego returned from his first two apparitions to find his uncle very ill. All that night and next day, Juan Diego tended to his uncle. Towards sunset, it became clear that Juan Bernardino was dying. Juan Diego set out at four the following morning, to bring back a [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priest]] to hear his uncle's [[Confession (religion)|confession]] and administer the [[Anointing of the Sick|last rites]].
While he was gone, Juan Bernardino became too weak to drink the [[medicine]] that had been left by his bedside, and he felt he was about to die. Suddenly the room was filled with light and a beautiful radiant lady appeared to him. Our Lady appeared to Juan Bernardino and cured him. He immediately felt that his body had recovered from the fever, and getting up, fell to his knees before the apparition. She told him that she had met Juan Diego and sent him to the [[bishop]] with her sacred image imprinted on his [[Tilmàtli|tilma]]. It was at this apparition that she identified herself as 'The Ever Virgin, Holy Mary of Guadalupe' Some analysts believe that she actually said not ''de Guadalupe'' but ''te [[coatlaxopeuh]]'' which many scholars translate differently; "the one that originates from the cliffs", ''who crushes the stone serpent'', "the one that has dominion of the serpent", etc.
=== Apparition to Juan Bernardino === (This account of the apparition occurs in the middle of the Guadalupe narrative, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Diego#Guadalupe_narrative.)
No sooner had Juan Diego demonstrated where the Lady of Heaven ordered her temple to be built than he begged to be excused. He wanted to go home to see his uncle Juan Bernardino, who had been very ill when Juan Diego left him and went to Tlatilolco to call a priest to confess and absolve him, the one whom the Lady of Heaven had told Juan Diego that she had already healed. But they would not let Juan Diego go alone, and instead accompanied him to his home. Arriving, they saw his uncle very happy and in no pain. He was astonished to see his nephew arrive accompanied and greatly honored, and he asked his nephew the reason why they did this and conferred honors upon him. His nephew answered that when he went to call the priest to confess and prepare his uncle, the Lady of Heaven appeared to him on Tepeyacac; she, telling him not to worry since his uncle was already in good health, consoled him much, and she sent him to Mexico, to see the Bishop, so that he might build her a house on Tepeyac. His uncle revealed that it was true that she healed him then and that he saw her the same way that she appeared to his nephew,, She told him that she was also sending him to Mexico to see the Bishop. Also then the Lady told him that when he went to see the Bishop, he should reveal what he saw and in what miraculous manner she had healed him and that he would properly name her, just as he needed to name her blessed image, the ever Virgin Holy Mary of Guadalupe.
Then they brought Juan Bernardino into the presence of the bishop, to come to inform and testify before him. The Bishop lodged both of them, him and his nephew, in his house for a few days, until the temple of Queen was built on Tepeyac, where Juan Diego had seen her. The Bishop moved into the main church the holy image of the beloved Lady of Heaven: he took it from the oratory of his palace where he was, for all people to see and admire her image.<ref> See the following website (in Spanish): https://www.ewtn.com/spanish/Maria/guadalupe.htm and the following website (in English and Nahuatl): http://pages.ucsd.edu/~dkjordan/nahuatl/nican/nican7.html </ref> <ref name="Castro Dopacio">{{cite book|author=María Jesús Castro Dopacio|title=Emperatriz de las Américas: La Virgen de Guadalupe en la literatura chicana|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d0vQv6YGsPsC&pg=PA27&dq=%22t%C3%A9rmino+%22Guadalupe%22+da+pie+a+una+gran+controversia%22+etimolog%C3%ADa+%22Ana+Castillo%22+%22r%C3%ADo+de+amor,+r%C3%ADo+de+luz%22+%22r%C3%ADo+de+lobos%22+%22la+que+aplasta+la+cabeza+de+la+serpiente%22|accessdate=21 December 2015|date=28 November 2011|publisher=Universitat de València|language=es|isbn=978-84-370-7758-1|page=27}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Sources== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=evp5S-1ijucC&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=Juan+Diego+Bernardino+Guadalupe&source=bl&ots=VKoN8J_WK8&sig=kD4ibs2YbCL8uxnU6W3mYayisDo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAzgUahUKEwiAiLrO9PLHAhVGJh4KHazWCXo#v=onepage&q=Juan%20Diego%20Bernardino%20Guadalupe&f=false ''Our Lady of Guadalupe: The Origins and Sources of a Mexican National Symbol''], by [[Stafford Poole]] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=CEM6yxXP9YAC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=Juan+Diego+Bernardino+Guadalupe&source=bl&ots=E7TESqF8bw&sig=ktrki8CLxs2CDeAhOKCv2enQ-Qc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFcQ6AEwDGoVChMIpffHhfPyxwIVSyweCh1oDQH4#v=onepage&q=Juan%20Diego%20Bernardino%20Guadalupe&f=false ''Our Lady of Guadalupe and Saint Juan Diego: The Historical Evidence''], by Eduardo Chávez *[https://books.google.com/books?id=F1y3uwi_xRcC&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15&dq=Juan+Diego+Bernardino+Guadalupe&source=bl&ots=-Nsz0KwG_b&sig=kQrsY63V8XqK-BCDxsf3x-aVA60&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFQQ6AEwC2oVChMIpffHhfPyxwIVSyweCh1oDQH4#v=onepage&q=Juan%20Diego%20Bernardino%20Guadalupe&f=false ''Mexican Spirituality: Its Sources and Mission in the Earliest Guadalupan Sermons''], by Francisco Schulte *[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNZ15Oow8XcC&pg=PA199&lpg=PA199&dq=Juan+Diego+Bernardino+Guadalupe&source=bl&ots=b0kO0BMNUf&sig=XSUPnbCuEKcAve2Xcvbi2wQjIK8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCEQ6AEwATgKahUKEwjXnMyH9PLHAhUF1B4KHU8sCbs#v=onepage&q=Juan%20Diego%20Bernardino%20Guadalupe&f=false ''Encyclopedia of Sacred Places''], by Norbert C. Brockman *[https://books.google.com/books?id=8aBdP_LyFZwC&pg=PA130&lpg=PA130&dq=Juan+Diego+Bernardino+Guadalupe&source=bl&ots=pGisPA1J4O&sig=kBLiteaeaKoaZ-_EAOXrU52IqGA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAjgKahUKEwjXnMyH9PLHAhUF1B4KHU8sCbs#v=onepage&q=Juan%20Diego%20Bernardino%20Guadalupe&f=false ''Hispanic/Latino Theology: Challenge and Promise''], edited by [[Ada Maria Isasi-Diaz]] and [[Fernando Segovia]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bernardino, Juan}} [[Category:1460 births]] [[Category:1544 deaths]] [[Category:Nahua people]] [[Category:Marian visionaries]] [[Category:Our Lady of Guadalupe]] [[Category:Mexican Roman Catholics]]

page.title: List of Bangla Academy Literary Award recipients (2010–19)

revision.text:
This is a list of the recipients of the [[Bangla Academy Literary Award]] from 2010 to 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://banglaacademy.org.bd/?page_id=1315|title=পুরস্কারপ্রাপ্তদের তালিকা|language=bn|trans-title=Winners list|accessdate=24 July 2017|publisher=Bangla Academy}}</ref>
== 2010 == 6 persons were awarded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-175704|title=Six receive Bangla Academy award|date=2011-02-27|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}}</ref> # [[Rubi Rahman]] (poetry) # Nasir Ahmed (poetry) # [[Bulbul Chowdhury]] (folk literature) # [[Khan Sarwar Murshid]] (essay and research) # [[Ajoy Roy]] (science and technology) # [[Shahjahan Kibria]] (juvenile literature)
== 2011 == 10 persons were awarded.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-223020|title=Awards go to 10|newspaper=The Daily Star|date=February 19, 2012|accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref> # Ashim Shaha (poetry) # [[Kamal Abdul Naser Chowdhury|Kamal Chowdhury]] (poetry) # [[Anisul Hoque]] (folk literature) # [[Abdullah Abu Sayeed]] (essay) # Biswajit Ghosh (research) # Khaliquzzaman Ilias (translation) # [[Belal Muhammad]] (literature on liberation war affairs) # Baren Chakrabarti (travel story) # Ali Ajgar (science, technology and environment) # Akhter Hossain (juvenile literature)
== 2012 == 9 persons were awarded.<ref>{{cite news |date=18 February 2013 |title=Bangla Academy Awards announced |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/18/bangla-academy-awards-announced |newspaper=bdnews24.com}}</ref> # Sanaul Haque Khan (poetry) # [[Abid Anwar]] (poetry) # {{Interlanguage link multi|Harishanker Jaldas|bn|3=হরিশংকর জলদাস}} (folk literature) # [[Sanat Kumar Saha]] (essay) # Khondokar Sirajul Haque (research) # [[Fakrul Alam]] (translation) # Mahbub Alam (Liberation War-related writings) # [[Tapan Chakrabarty]] (science, technology and environment) # Mahbub Talukder (juvenile literature)
== 2013 == 11 persons were awarded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sandbox.thedailystar.net/eleven-win-bangla-academy-award-9280|title=Eleven win Bangla Academy award|date=2014-01-31|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}}</ref> # [[Helal Hafiz]] (poetry) # [[Purabi Basu]] (folk literature) # Mofidul Haq (essay) # Jamil Chowdhury (research) # Provangshu Tripura (research) # [[Kaiser Haq]] (translation) # [[Haroon Habib|Harun Habib]] (Liberation War-related writings) # Mahfuzur Rahman (autobiography and travel story) # [[Shahidul Islam (writer)|Shahidul Islam]] (science, technology and environment) # Kaiser Chowdhury (juvenile literature) # Aslam Sunny (juvenile literature)
== 2014 == 7 persons were awarded.<ref>{{cite news |date=29 January 2015 |title=Bangla Academy awards for 2014 announced |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/01/29/bangla-academy-awards-for-2014-announced |newspaper=bdnews24.com}}</ref> # Shihab Sarkar (poetry) # Zakir Talukder (fiction) # [[Shantanu Kaiser]] (essay) # Bhuyian Iqbal (research) # Abu Mohammad Delwar Hossain (literature on liberation war) # Moynus Sultan (travel story) # Khaleque bin Zainuddin (juvenile literature)
== 2015 == 11 persons were awarded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/11-honoured-bangla-academy-awards-208660|title=11 honoured with Bangla Academy awards|date=2016-01-28|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}}</ref> # [[Altaf Hossain]] (poetry) # [[Shaheen Akhtar]] (fiction) # [[Abul Momen]] (essay) # [[Atiur Rahman]] (essay) # [[Moniruzzaman (linguist, University of Chittagong)|Moniruzzaman]] (research) # [[Abdus Selim]] (translation) # [[Tajul Mohammad]] (literature on liberation war) # [[Faruq Ahmed Choudhury]] (biography and travel story) # [[Masum Reza]] (drama) # [[Sharif Khan]] (science, technology and environment) # [[Sujan Barua]] (juvenile literature)
== 2016 == 7 persons were awarded.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/literature/bangla-academy-sahitya-puroshkar-2016-announced-1349704|title=Bangla Academy Sahitya Puroshkar 2016 announced|date= January 23, 2017 |accessdate= January 24, 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref> # [[Abu Hasan Shahriar]] (poetry) # [[Shahaduz Zaman]] (fiction) # Morshed Shafiul Hasan (essay and research) # [[Niaz Zaman]] (translation) # MA Hasan (literature on the liberation war) # [[Noorjahan Bose]] (autobiography/memoir) # [[Rashed Rouf]] (juvenile literature)
== 2017 == 12 persons were awarded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/top-news/12-get-bangla-academy-award-2017-bangladesh-sahitya-puraskar-1525927|title=12 get Bangla Academy Award|date=2018-01-27|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}}</ref> # {{ill|Mohammad Sadik|bn|মোহাম্মদ সাদিক}} (poetry) # {{ill|Maruful Islam|bn|মারুফুল ইসলাম}} (poetry) # {{ill|Mamun Hossain (writer)|lt=Mamun Hossain|bn|মামুন হুসাইন}} (fiction) # {{ill|Mahbubul Haque (writer)|lt=Mahbubul Haque|bn|মাহবুবুল হক}} (essay) # {{ill|Rafiqullah Khan|bn|রফিকউল্লাহ্ খান}} (research) # {{ill|Aminul Islam Bhuiyan|bn|আমিনুল ইসলাম ভুঁইয়া}} (translation) # [[Kamrul Hasan Bhuiyan]] (literature on liberation war) # Surma Jahid (literature on liberation war) # [[Shakoor Majid]] (travelogue) # [[Malay Bhowmick]] (drama) # {{ill|Moshtak Ahmed|bn|মোশতাক আহমেদ}} (science, technology and environment) # {{ill|Jharna Dash Purokhayshto|bn|ঝর্ণা দাশ পুরকায়স্থ}} (juvenile literature)
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of Bangla Academy Literary Award recipients (2010-19)}} [[Category:Bengali literary awards]] [[Category:Bangladeshi literary awards]] [[Category:Lists of award winners]]

page.title: List of Britain's Got Talent finalists (series 7)

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:KolbertBot|HTTP→HTTPS]] (v485)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Use British English|date=December 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Britain's Got Talent'' finalists (series 7)}} {{BLP sources|date=June 2013}} The [[Britain's Got Talent (series 7)|seventh series]] of '''''[[Britain's Got Talent]]''''' started on 13 April 2013 and ended on 8 June 2013. The finalists are given in the order in which they finished, thus Attraction won, Jack Carroll finished second and so on.
== Attraction == {{main|Attraction (shadow theatre group)}} '''Attraction''' are a Hungarian shadow theatre group who won the competition beating joint favorite, Jack Carroll.
== Jack Carroll == {{main|Jack Carroll (comedian)}} '''Jack Carroll''' is a comedian who suffers from [[Cerebral Palsy]].
== Richard & Adam == {{main|Richard & Adam}} '''Richard and Adam Johnson''' are two opera singing brothers. Their act was disrupted in the final when one of their violinists when out and attacked the judges with eggs. They finished third place. In 2014, they returned for a combined performance with Attraction.
== Steve Hewlett == '''Steve Hewlett''', is a ventriloquist from [[Sussex]]. He and his wife Nina have a daughter,<ref>[http://roarglobal.com/clients/profile/steve-hewlett Steve Hewlett | ROAR Broadcasting<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122054653/http://roarglobal.com/clients/profile/steve-hewlett |date=22 January 2014 }}</ref> who was born in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/cromer_pier_show_s_vent_steve_hewlett_celebrates_birth_of_baby_after_summer_season_closes_1_1089858|title=Cromer pier show’s “vent” Steve Hewlett celebrates birth of baby after summer season closes|last=Batson|first=David|date=13 October 2011|work=[[Eastern Daily Press]]|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref>
He auditioned with a puppet called 'Arthur Lager', depicted as an old man with grey hair. Hewlett's audition was aired in a montage on 18 May 2013. He made it through, and subsequently through to the semi-finals. He appeared again in the semi-final on 1 June with Arthur Lager, and a puppet designed to resemble Simon Cowell, one of the judges. The routine involved Arthur flirting with [[Amanda Holden]]. After his performance, people took to Twitter to voice their approval. He landed in the top three, and with eventual winners [[Attraction (shadow theatre group)|Attraction]] already through to the final, it was down to the judges to choose the second place in the final between Hewlett and [[Jordan O'Keefe]]. It was a split decision, so it was referred back to the public vote, revealing that with 15.1% of the vote, O'Keefe was through to the final, compared to Hewlett's 12%.
However, earlier in the week, it was revealed that the judges were going to choose a wildcard act out of the third-placed finishers to compete in the final. Hewlett was seen as the popular choice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/06/08/bgts-steve-hewlett-impresses-twitter-as-hes-named-wildcard-act-3833635/|title=BGT's Steve Hewlett impresses Twitter as he's named wildcard act - Metro News|work=Metro|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-reviews/ian-hyland-britains-talent-itll-1930077|title=Ian Hyland on Britain's Got Talent: It'll be travesty if Attraction don't win - Ian Hyland - Mirror Online|author=Ian Hyland|work=mirror|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-simon-cowell-teases-david-walliams-wildcard-choice-steve-hewlett-or-joseph-hall/|title=Britain's Got Talent 2014 ITV - Unreality TV|work=Unreality TV|accessdate=2 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029185251/http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-simon-cowell-teases-david-walliams-wildcard-choice-steve-hewlett-or-joseph-hall/|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It was revealed on the night that Hewlett was indeed the wildcard. He performed again in the final with Arthur Lager (now wearing a Onesie), the puppet of [[Simon Cowell]] (wearing a swimsuit and life jacket),as well as a puppet of [[Sinitta]], along with a musical number in the shape of "[[We Go Together (song)|We Go Together]]" from ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'' at the end, involving the Simon and Sinitta puppets. Despite rave reviews from the judges, Hewlett finished in fourth, just narrowly missing out on the top three with 14.7% of the vote, compared to [[Richard & Adam]]'s 15.4%.
Hewlett has previously headlined [[Cromer Pier]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/what-s-on/cromer_pier_ventriloquist_steve_hewlett_misses_out_on_winning_britain_s_got_talent_1_2228571|title=Cromer Pier ventriloquist Steve Hewlett misses out on winning Britain’s Got Talent|author=Sophie Wyllie|work=Eastern Daily Press|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> It was revealed the day after the final that Hewlett had been signed to entertainment agency ROAR Global.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-jack-carroll-attraction-jordan-okeefe-steve-hewlett-francine-lewis-sign-with-new-agency/|title=Britain's Got Talent 2013: Jack Carroll, Attraction, Jordan O'Keefe, Steve Hewlett, Francine Lewis sign with new agency - Unreality TV|work=Unreality TV|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>
== Luminites == '''Luminites''' are a band consisting of members JJ, Corey, Ben (R Tizt) and Steph. They auditioned with 'Hurts So Good' and were put through to the next round, and the semi-finals. They performed 'To Love Somebody' in the live semi-final on 30 May. They received 35.6% of the vote and won the semi-final, therefore were sent through to the final. They performed 'Hurts So Good' again and finished in fifth place with 6.8% of the vote. They were described as "like a British [[The Black Eyed Peas|Black Eyed Peas]]" by judge Simon Cowell.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/s107/britains-got-talent/news/a488416/bgt-jack-carroll-luminites-to-sign-deals-with-simon-cowell.html|title='BGT': Jack Carroll, Luminites to sign deals with Simon Cowell?|work=Digital Spy|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> They also revealed that they had been bullied at school because people deemed their musical aspirations as uncool, but mentioned that they intend to be role models.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-faves-luminites-reveal-bullying-hell-didnt-stop-them-chasing-their-dreams/|title=Britain's Got Talent 2013: Faves Luminites reveal bullying hell didn’t stop them chasing their dreams! - Unreality TV|work=Unreality TV|accessdate=2 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021200719/http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-faves-luminites-reveal-bullying-hell-didnt-stop-them-chasing-their-dreams/|archivedate=21 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The band were founded in 2011. They have uploaded videos of their covers on YouTube. They stated that fans' comments encouraged them to audition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/04/29/bgts-luminites-we-havent-spoken-to-anyone-for-two-days-just-replying-to-people-on-the-internet-3697403/|title=Britain's Got Talent buskers Luminites overwhelmed at public reaction - Metro News|work=Metro|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> They frequently busked on the streets of London.<ref name="metro">{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2011/12/05/busking-pop-band-spotted-on-youtube-to-release-christmas-single-for-charity-245210/|title=Busking pop band spotted on YouTube to release Christmas single for charity - Metro News|author=metrowebukmetro|work=Metro|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> They also released a charity single in 2011.<ref name="metro" />
It was reported a day after the final that Simon Cowell was intending to sign them to his record label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/4961386/jack-carroll-and-luminites-to-be-next-big-stars.html|title=The Sun|work=thesun.co.uk|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> They announced on 17 June that they were to embark on a 3-day tour, visiting London, Manchester and Birmingham from 24–26 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-the-luminites-announce-uk-mini-tour-telling-fans-were-ridiculously-excited/|title=Britain's Got Talent 2014 ITV - Unreality TV|work=Unreality TV|accessdate=2 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021201320/http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/britains-got-talent/britains-got-talent-2013-the-luminites-announce-uk-mini-tour-telling-fans-were-ridiculously-excited/|archivedate=21 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 15 August 2013 the band announced they had been signed to Sony.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=531088513628179&set=a.196512907085743.45800.179373435466357&type=1|title=Facebook|work=facebook.com|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thetalentzone.co.uk/musictv/bgt/6408/luminites-set-to-make-first-album-after-signing-recording-deal-with-sony/|title=Luminites set to make first album after signing recording deal with Sony|work=Reality TV|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>
It was also revealed during their time in the show that [[will.i.am]] had been coaching them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/thevoice/4951404/Will-i-am-Luminites-BGT-Simon-Cowell.html|title=The Sun|work=thesun.co.uk|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> However, during an interview the Luminites absolutely denied that and made it clear they had a 5-second photo opportunity with him and that was the extent of the contact.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x10ofny_britain-s-got-talent-luminites-prepare-for-final_lifestyle#.UdQAnoF-_8c|title=Britain's Got Talent: Luminites prepare for final|author=ITN Entertainment|work=Dailymotion|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> On 15 August, the group announced that they were signed in an [[Instagram]] video. They released their debut single "Do Something" on 10 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/s107/britains-got-talent/news/a513473/britains-got-talent-luminites-to-release-debut-single-do-something.html|title='Britain's Got Talent' Luminites to release debut single 'Do Something'|work=Digital Spy|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>
== Jordan O'Keefe == '''Jordan O'Keefe''' (born 1994) is a singer-songwriter from [[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]]. Before the show, he previously worked as an estate agent.
Upon auditioning for ''BGT'' (the audition was aired on 20 April 2013), he stated that he initially applied for a music course in college, but his father had it changed to business. He stated that he was 'raging' at the time, but that he had forgiven his father. He auditioned with a guitar-led version of [[Little Things (One Direction song)|Little Things]] by [[One Direction]], receiving rave reviews from the judges, receiving four yeses and being put through to the next round, and subsequently the live semi-finals.
He performed in the live semi-final on 1 June, performing "[[I Will Always Love You]]", again receiving rave reviews from the judges. He landed in the top three – with [[Attraction (shadow theatre group)|Attraction]] already through to the final (and who became eventual winners), the judges had to pick between O'Keefe and ventriloquist Steve Hewlett. It was a split decision, so was referred back to the public vote, and it was revealed that O'Keefe had the higher amount of votes and was automatically through to the final. Hewlett was chosen as the wildcard for the final a week later.
O'Keefe performed "[[Firework (song)|Firework]]" in the final on 8 June, and finished in sixth place with 3.7% of the vote.
It was revealed during his time in ''BGT'' that he was previously mates with [[Niall Horan]], a member of [[One Direction]] and that he was his inspiration to win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/06/05/britains-got-talent-finalist-jordan-okeefe-one-directions-niall-horan-is-my-inspiration-to-win-3829359/|title=Britain's Got Talent finalist Jordan O’Keefe: 1D's Niall Horan is my inspiration - Metro News|work=Metro|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> He also mentioned that he had audition for X Factor the same year, and just narrowly missed out on being in One Direction. It was revealed the day after the final that O'Keefe, along with many of the other finalists, had been signed to the entertainment agency ROAR Global.
O'Keefe was the support act for [[Jonathan and Charlotte]] on their UK arena tour. Jordan is now in the progress of releasing his single. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/britain_got_talent/4976975/BGT-Gabz-to-release-Lighters.html|title=The Sun|work=thesun.co.uk|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>
== Gabz == {{main|Gabz}} Gabz is a singer-rapper-songwriter from [[Stevenage]].
==Arisxandra== '''Arisxandra Libantino''' (born 2001) is a Philippines-born English singer from Nottingham of Filipino descent. She attends Trinity School. She moved to the UK at an early age.
In her audition in February (aired on 13 April), she performed 'One Night Only' and received a standing ovation from the judges, as well as a positive response. However, upon the broadcast of her audition during the launch episode of the series, many viewers were outraged at that the fact that she was singing a song about a [[one-night stand]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/showbiz/392076/Outrage-as-11-year-old-schoolgirl-sings-about-a-one-night-stand-on-Britain-s-Got-Talent|title=Outrage as 11-year-old schoolgirl sings about a one night stand on Britain's Got Talent|last=McCormack|first=Kirsty|date=15 April 2013|work=[[Daily Express]]|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref> Vivienne Pattison, director of [[Mediawatch UK]], said the show was "sexualising children" and that "We are sleepwalking into a situation where pornography is the norm."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2309082/Britains-Got-Talent-viewers-backlash-lap-dancer-schoolgirl-11-singing-night-stands.html|title=Britain's Got Sleaze: BGT viewers' backlash over the lap-dancer and the schoolgirl of 11 singing about one-night stands|last=Cable|first=Simon|date=14 April 2013|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> A few weeks later however, she was shown being put through to the semi-finals. Her family stated that they were desperate for her to win to end their poverty.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/bgt-child-singer-arisxandra-libantino-1912450|title=BGT child singer Arisxandra Libantino: Sensation's family desperate for her to win to end their poverty|author=Halina Watts|date=25 May 2013|work=mirror|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>
In the semi-final on 27 May, she performed 'I Have Nothing' and received rave reviews from the judges. She landed in the top three of the semi-final, and it was down to the judges to pick the second place for the final with [[Richard and Adam Johnson]] already through. Simon Cowell and Alesha Dixon opted for dance group Youth Creation, while David Walliams and Amanda Holden opted for Arisxandra. The judges' vote was a split decision so therefore Arisxandra was announced to have received more public votes and was sent through to the final.
She performed 'The Voice Within' in the final on 8 June. David Walliams said "You have an incredible, natural talent. I think the thing that children often miss is the emotion in a song but you caught it beautifully tonight." Alesha Dixon said "Such a massive song to take on and you did it with ease. The most impressive thing is your control. You rose to the occasion tonight." Amanda Holden said "You did yourself proud, you started off so whispery and quiet but when you went for it, you went for it. It was an electrifying performance." Simon Cowell finished with "You started off a little bit tentative and then you got yourself together. I genuinely, after this, don’t know what’s going to happen tonight." She finished in eighth place with 2.9% of the vote.
== Pre Skool == '''Pre Skool''' are a dance group from [[Neath]], [[Port Talbot]] in [[South Wales]], and essentially the younger version of Nu Sxool who reached the final the previous year. They finished in ninth place with 2.8% of the vote. They're aged 6–9. They are choreographed by Terry Michael, the man behind last year's Nu Sxool.
Pre Skool have been involved in the [[Pixar]] film ''[[Planes (film)|Planes]]''. Both Pre Skool and Nu Sxool were invited to the premier of ''Planes'' in [[Leicester Square]]. Pre Skool and Nu Sxool were asked to make a dance routine to one of the songs from Disney Planes. The video is a great success.
== Francine Lewis == {{Main|Francine Lewis}} Francine Lewis is an impressionist and stand up comedian.
== Asanda == {{main|Asanda}} '''Asanda Jezile''' (born 2001) is a singer from London. Her parents moved to the UK from [[Eastern Cape]] South Africa over 10 years ago.<ref name="iol">{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/the-star/bgt-s-asanda-may-get-record-deal-1.1530071#.Ubr62ufrzu0|title=BGT’s Asanda may get record deal|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>

of element [[platinum]] with [[Jorge Juan y Santacilia]] (1713–1773) *''[[Arnold of Villanova|Arnold of '''Villanova''']]'' (c. 1235–1311), alchemist and physician, he discovered [[carbon monoxide]] and pure [[alcohol]] == Social scientists == *[[Martín de Azpilcueta|Martín de '''Azpilicueta''']] (1492–1586), [[Economics|economist]], member of the [[School of Salamanca]], precursor of the quantitative theory of money *[[Manuel Castells|Manuel '''Castells''']] (born 1942), sociologist, author of trilogy ''The Information Age'' *[[María Ángeles Durán]] (born 1942), sociologist and economist *'''[[:es:Manuel Fernández López (sindicalista)|Manuel Fernández López]]''' (1947–2014) *[[Salvador Giner|Salvador '''Giner''']] (born 1934), sociologist, he had researched on social theory, sociology of culture and modern industrial society *[[Jesus Huerta de Soto|Jesús '''Huerta de Soto''']] (born 1956), major [[Austrian School]] economist *[[Juan J. Linz|Juan José '''Linz''']] (1926–2013), [[Sterling Professor]] of Political and Social Science at [[Yale University|Yale]]; [[Prince of Asturias Award]] (1987) and [[Johan Skytte Prize in Political Science|Johan Skytte Prize]] (1996) laureate *[[Claudio Sánchez-Albornoz y Menduiña|Claudio '''Sánchez-Albornoz''']] (1893–1984), historian, prominent specialist in [[Spain in the Middle Ages|medieval Spanish history]] *[[Joseph de la Vega|Joseph de la '''Vega''']] (1650–1692), businessman, wrote ''Confusion of Confusions'' (1688), first book on [[stock market]]s *[[Francisco de Vitoria|Francisco de '''Vitoria''']] (c. 1480/86–1546), member of the [[School of Salamanca]], precursor of [[international law]] theory == Sports == {{See also|Category:Spanish sportspeople|List of Spanish sportspeople}} === Athletics === *[[Fermín Cacho Ruiz|Fermín '''Cacho Ruiz''']] (born 1969), [[1500 metres]] gold ([[Athletics at the 1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Olympics]]) and silver ([[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Olympics]]) medalist *[[Francisco Javier Gómez Noya]] (born 1983), triathlon silver ([[2012 Summer Olympics|London 2012]]) medalist; four times [[ITU World Triathlon Series|ITU Triathlon world champion]] === Basketball === *[[Antonio Díaz-Miguel|Antonio '''Díaz-Miguel''']] (1933–2000), coach, enshrined in the [[Basketball Hall of Fame]] in 1997 *[[Pau Gasol|Pau '''Gasol''']] (born 1980), [[FC Barcelona Bàsquet|FC Barcelona]] and [[Los Angeles Lakers]] player, 2001-02 [[NBA Rookie of the Year Award]] winner; [[2006 FIBA World Championship|2006 FIBA W.C.]] [[Most Valuable Player|MVP]] *[[Marc Gasol| Marc '''Gasol''']] (born 1985), Player for [[Memphis Grizzlies]] (2008-Present) *[[Fernando Martín Espina|Fernando '''Martín''']] (1962–1989), [[CB Estudiantes|Estudiantes]], [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]] and [[Portland Trail Blazers]] player *[[Juan Carlos Navarro (basketball)|Juan Carlos '''Navarro''']] (born 1980), [[FC Barcelona Bàsquet|FC Barcelona]] and [[Memphis Grizzlies]] player === Boxing === *[[Pedro Carrasco|Pedro '''Carrasco''']] (1943–2001), 1967 European Lightweight Champion; 1971 [[World Boxing Council|WBC]]'s World [[Lightweight]] Champion *[[Javier Castillejo|Javier '''Castillejo''']] (born 1968), two-time [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] World Jr. Middleweight Champion and one-time [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] [[Middleweight]] champion === Cycling === *[[Federico Bahamontes|Federico Martín '''Bahamontes''']] (born 1928), [[1959 Tour de France]] winner *[[Juan José Cobo|Juan José '''Cobo''']] (born 1981), [[2011 Vuelta a España]] winner *[[Alberto Contador|Alberto '''Contador''']] (born 1982), three-time [[Tour de France]] (2007,2009,2010), [[2008 Giro d'Italia]], [[2008 Vuelta a España]] winner *[[Pedro Delgado|Pedro '''Delgado''']] (born 1960), [[1988 Tour de France]] winner *[[Óscar Freire|Óscar '''Freire''']] (born 1976), three-time [[UCI World Championships|World Cycling Champion]] (1999, 2001, 2004) *[[José Manuel Fuente|José Manuel '''Fuente''']] (1945–1996), twice [[Vuelta a España]] winner (1972, 1974), second in [[Giro d'Italia]] (1972), third in [[Tour de France]] (1973) *[[Roberto Heras|Roberto '''Heras''']] (born 1974), three-time [[Vuelta a España]] winner (2000, 2003, 2004) *[[Miguel Indurain|Miguel '''Indurain''']] (born 1964), gold medalist ([[Cycling at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Olympics]]), 1995 [[UCI World Championships#World Time-Trial Champions|World Time-Trial Champion]], World Hour recordman (1994), five consecutive times [[Tour de France]] winner (1991–1995), twice [[Giro d'Italia]] winner (1992, 1993) *[[Joan Llaneras|Joan '''Llaneras''']] (born 1969), gold medalist ([[Cycling at the 2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Olympics]]), silver medalist ([[Cycling at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Olympics]]), seven-times [[UCI Track World Championships, Men|World Points race or Madison Track Cycling Champion]] (1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2006, 2007) *[[Luis Ocaña|Luis '''Ocaña''']] (1945–1994), [[1973 Tour de France]] winner *[[Abraham Olano|Abraham '''Olano''']] (born 1970), 1995 World Cycling Champion and 1998 [[UCI World Championships#World Time-Trial Champions|World Time-Trial Champion]] *[[Óscar Pereiro|Óscar '''Pereiro''']] (born 1977), [[2006 Tour de France]] winner *[[Samuel Sánchez|'''Samu'''el Sánchez]] (born 1978), [[Cycling at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's road race|Beijing 2008 Olympic Road Race Gold Medal]] *[[Carlos Sastre|Carlos '''Sastre''']] (born 1975), [[2008 Tour de France]] winner *[[Joane Somarriba|Joane '''Somarriba''']] (born 1972), three-time [[Grande Boucle]] winner (2000, 2001, 2003) *[[Guillermo Timoner|Guillermo '''Timoner''']] (born 1926), six-time [[UCI Track World Championships, Men|World Motor paced Track Cycling Champion]] (1955, 1959, 1960, 1962, 1964, 1965) === Football (soccer) === [[File:Fernando Torres Spain.jpg|thumb|100px|right|Torres celebrating victory with Spain at Euro 2008]] *[[Iker Casillas|Iker '''Casillas''']] (born 1981), goalkeeper and [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]; captain of Spain's team that won UEFA Euro 2008, the 2010 FIFA World Cup and Euro 2012 *[[Francisco Gento|Francisco '''Gento''']] (born 1933), Real Madrid player; winner of six [[UEFA Champions League]] *[[Raúl (footballer)|'''Raúl''' González]] (born 1977), first player to reach 50 goals in UEFA Champions League *[[Xavi|'''Xavi''' Hernández]] (born 1980), midfielder and [[FC Barcelona]] player; [[UEFA Euro 2008]] MVP *[[Andrés Iniesta|Andrés '''Iniesta''']] (born 1984), midfielder and [[FC Barcelona]] player; scored the winning goal at the 2010 FIFA World Cup Final; [[UEFA Euro 2012]] MVP *[[Fernando Torres|Fernando '''Torres''']] (born 1984), striker and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] player; scored the winning goal at the Euro 2008 Final; winner of Golden Boot at Euro 2012 *[[David Villa|David '''Villa''']] (born 1981), striker and [[FC Barcelona]] player; Spain's all-time top goalscorer *[[Andoni Zubizarreta|Andoni '''Zubizarreta''']] (born 1961), Spanish international === Golf === *[[Seve Ballesteros|Seve '''Ballesteros''']] (1957–2011), winner of five [[Men's major golf championships|major championships]] *[[Sergio García|Sergio '''García''']] (born 1980), winner of a major championship *[[Miguel Ángel Jiménez|Miguel Ángel '''Jiménez''']] (born 1964), winner of 13 European Tour titles winner *[[José María Olazábal|José María '''Olazábal''']] (born 1966), winner of two major championships === Motor sports === *[[Fernando Alonso|Fernando '''Alonso''']] (born 1981), 2005 and 2006 [[Formula One]] [[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions|World Champion]] *[[Jaime Alguersuari|Jaime '''Alguersuari''']] (born 1990), 2008 British Formula Three champion *[[Álvaro Bautista|Álvaro '''Bautista''']] (born 1984), motorcycle racing raider, 125cc champion of the World in 2006 *[[Carlos Checa|Carlos '''Checa''']] (born 1972), [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|GP motorcycle racing]] rider and [[List of Superbike World champions|Superbike World Champion]] in 2011 *[[Marc Coma|Marc '''Coma''']] (born 1976), won the [[Dakar Rally]] in 2006 *[[Àlex Crivillé|Àlex '''Crivillé''']] (born 1970), 500cc GP motorcycle racing [[List of Grand Prix motorcycle racing World Champions|World Champion]] in 1999 *[[Marc Gené|Marc '''Gené''']] (born 1974), [[Formula One]] driver *[[Jorge Lorenzo|Jorge '''Lorenzo''']] (born 1987), 2006 and 2007 [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|GP motorcycle racing]] 250cc World Champion, 2010, 2012, and 2015 MotoGP World Champion *[[Marc Márquez|Marc '''Márquez''']] (born 1993), is a [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|Grand Prix]] motorcycle [[road racing|road racer]], and is the 2013, 2014, 2016 and 2017 Moto GP World Champion *[[Jorge Martínez (motorcyclist)|Jorge '''Martínez Aspar''']] (born 1962), GP motorcycle racing rider, four-time World Champion *[[Pedro de la Rosa|Pedro '''Martínez de la Rosa''']] (born 1971), Formula One driver *[[Ángel Nieto|Ángel '''Nieto''']] (born 1947), GP motorcycle racing rider, 12+1 times World Champion *[[Daniel Pedrosa|Daniel '''Pedrosa''']] (born 1985), youngest GP motorcycle racing World Champion of 125cc and 250cc *[[Carlos Sainz|Carlos '''Sainz''']] (born 1962), 1990 and 1992 [[World Rally Championship|World Rally Champion]] and 2010 Dakar Rally winner *[[Carlos Sainz, Jr.|Carlos '''Sainz''', Jr.]] (born 1994), Formula One driver === Rugby union=== *[[Oriol Ripol|Oriol '''Ripol''']], professional rugby union player for [[Worcester Warriors]]; considered the greatest Spaniard to ever play the game *[[Cédric Garcia|Cédric '''Garcia''']], professional rugby player for [[Aviron Bayonnais]] === Tennis === *[[Galo Blanco|Galo '''Blanco''']] (born 1976), professional tennis player *[[Sergi Bruguera|Sergi '''Bruguera''']] (born 1971), [[1993 French Open|1993]] and [[1994 French Open]] Men's Singles Champion *[[Àlex Corretja|Àlex '''Corretja''']] (born 1974), [[1998 ATP Tour World Championships|1998 ATP Tour World Champion]] *[[Albert Costa|Albert '''Costa''']] (born 1975), [[2002 French Open]] Men's Singles Champion *[[Juan Carlos Ferrero|Juan Carlos '''Ferrero''']] (born 1980), [[2003 French Open]] Men's Singles Champion *[[Andrés Gimeno|Andrés '''Gimeno''']] (born 1937), [[1972 French Open]] Men's Singles Champion *[[Conchita Martínez|Conchita '''Martínez''']] (born 1972), [[1994 Wimbledon Championships|1994 Wimbledon]] Women's Singles Champion *[[Carlos Moyá|Carlos '''Moyá''']] (born 1976), [[1998 French Open]] Men's Singles Champion *[[Garbiñe Muguruza|Garbiñe '''Muguruza''']] (born 1993), [[2016 French Open – Women's Singles|2016 French Open]] and [[2017 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles|2017 Wimbledon]] Women's Singles Champion *[[Rafael Nadal|Rafael '''Nadal''']] (born 1986), former World Number 1, [[2005 French Open]], [[2006 French Open]], [[2007 French Open]], [[2008 French Open]], [[2010 French Open]], [[2011 French Open]], [[2012 French Open]] [[2013 French Open]], [[2014 French Open]], [[2017 French Open]], [[2008 Wimbledon]], [[2010 Wimbledon]], [[2009 Australian Open]], [[2010 US Open (tennis)|2010 US Open]], [[2013 US Open (tennis)|2013 US Open]], [[2017 US Open (tennis)|2017 US Open]] Men's Singles Champion, [[Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|2008 Olympics]] and [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's Doubles|2016 Olympics]] gold medallist *[[Manuel Orantes|Manuel '''Orantes''']] (born 1949), 1975 [[U.S. Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]] Men's Singles Champion *[[Virginia Ruano Pascual|Virginia '''Ruano Pascual''']] (born 1973), eight [[Grand Slam title|Grand Slam]] Doubles titles winner *[[Arantxa Sánchez Vicario|Arantxa '''Sánchez Vicario''']] (born 1971), ten Grand Slam titles winner (four singles, six doubles) *[[Emilio Sánchez|Emilio '''Sánchez Vicario''']] (born 1965), three Grand Slam Doubles titles winner *[[Javier Sánchez|Javier '''Sánchez Vicario''']] professional tennis player, brother of Aranxta *[[Manuel Santana|Manuel '''Santana''']] (born 1938), 5 Grand Slam titles winner (four singles, one doubles) *[[Fernando Verdasco|Fernando '''Verdasco''' Carmona]] (born 1983), professional tennis player === Wrestling === *'''[[Kane (wrestler)|Kane]]''' (born 1967), [[WWE World Heavyweight Championship|WWF Championship]], [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)|World Heavyweight Championship]], [[ECW World Heavyweight Championship|ECW Championship]], [[WCW World Tag Team Championship]], [[WWE Hardcore Championship|WWF Hardcore Championship]], [[WWE Intercontinental Championship|WWF/E Intercontinental Championship]], [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|WWF/E World Tag Team Championship]] == Others == *[[María Josefa Cerrato Rodríguez]] (1897 - 1981) first woman veterinarian *[[José Andrés|José '''Andrés''']] (born 1969), [[chef]] *[[Ferran Adrià|Ferran '''Adrià''']] (born 1962), chef *[[Joaquín Cortés|Joaquín '''Cortés''']] (born 1969), dancer *[[Juan March Ordinas|Juan '''March Ordinas''']] (1880–1962), politician and businessman *[[Federica Montseny|Federica '''Montseny''']] (1905–1994), [[anarchism|anarchist]], politician and writer *[[Amancio Ortega Gaona]] (born 1936), entrepreneur *[[Juan Pujol (alias Garbo)|Juan '''Pujol''']], alias ''Garbo'' (1912–1988), double agent who played a key role in the success of [[Normandy Landings|D-Day]] towards the end of World War II *[[Tamara Rojo|Tamara '''Rojo''']] (born 1974), ''[[prima ballerina]]'' of the London's [[Royal Ballet, London|Royal Ballet]] (since 2000); [[Prince of Asturias Award]] of Arts laureate (2005) *[[Diego Salcedo (soldier)|Diego '''Salcedo''']] (1575–1644), revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=May 2011}}
This is a listing of notable people born in, or notable for their association with, [[South Sumatra]].
__NOTOC__ {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}
==A== * [[Ambrizal]], footballer who is currently playing for [[Persija]] ([[Palembang]]) * [[Jules Ancion]], [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[field hockey]] player who competed at the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] ([[Palembang]]) * [[Putty Armein]], ten-pin bowler ([[Palembang]])
==C== * [[Choo Hoey]], [[Singapore]]an musician and conductor ([[Palembang]])
==G== * [[Great Lady of Gresik]], noblewoman ([[Palembang]])
==M== * [[A. T. Mahmud]], renowned composer of 500 children's songs from [[Indonesia]] ([[Palembang]])
==N== * [[Alex Noerdin]], Governor of [[South Sumatra]] ([[Palembang]])
==N== * [[Emil Salim]], economist and former Minister of [[Indonesia]] ([[Lahat Regency]])
==R== * [[Hatta Rajasa]], Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs ([[Palembang]])
==S== * [[Shi Jin Qing]], late 14th century chieftain ([[Palembang]])
==Y== * [[Tantowi Yahya]], presenter, country singer and entrepreneur ([[Palembang]])
{{South Sumatra}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of People From South Sumatra}} [[Category:People from South Sumatra|*]] [[Category:Lists of people by place]]

revision.comment: /* Equine interests */ update
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Madeleine Pickens | image = US Navy 081003-N-2688M-095 Guests cut the ribbon at Naval Medical Center San Diego for the grand opening of the second Fisher House.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Pickens (4th from left) at a ribbon-cutting for a 2008 grand opening at the [[Naval Medical Center San Diego]] | birth_name = Madeleine Baker | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|3|5}} | birth_place = [[Kirkuk]], [[Iraq]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | residence = | education = | occupation = Business Owner, philanthropist | party = | spouse = include [[Allen E. Paulson]] (1988-2000) and [[T. Boone Pickens]] (2005-2012) | children = Dominique Richter | parents = | other_names=Madeleine Farris, Madeleine Richter, Madeleine Paulson | religion = | honors = {{plainlist| * Equine Advocates Award (2007) * [[ABC News|ABC News ''Person of the Week'']] (21 November 2008) }}}} '''Madeleine Anne Pickens''' is a business woman and philanthropist who has lived in the United States since 1969. She is a developer of and stockholder in the Del Mar Country Club in [[Rancho Santa Fe, California]], and the owner of the Mustang Monument: Wild Horse Eco-Resort near [[Wells, Nevada]] and the founder of Saving America's Mustangs. She is also a [[thoroughbred]] [[Horse racing|racehorse]] owner and breeder. She is the widow of American businessman [[Allen E. Paulson]] and former wife of millionaire [[T. Boone Pickens]].
==Background== Madeleine Pickens was born Madeleine Baker on March 5, 1947<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Madeleine-Pickens/6000000016066210079|title=Madeleine A. Pickens|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> in [[Kirkuk]], [[Iraq]]<ref name="cfr.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/united-states/conversation-t-boone-pickens/p18621|title=A Conversation with T. Boone Pickens|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> where her father, Bill Baker, was a British oil executive.<ref name=sh>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundhorseconference.com/conference/madeleine.php|title=Sound Horse Conference - Conference Proceedings|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> He was also a golf course designer, who built a golf course in Kirkuk and cut down his golf clubs to teach the five-year old Madeleine to play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hireveterans.com/company/87458/Del-Mar-Country-Club/|title=Hire Veterans - Jobs for Veterans - Job Board Hiring U.S. Military Veterans Employment Careers: Del Mar Country Club|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> After her family left Iraq, Pickens grew up in France and England,<ref name=sh /> where Baker designed several courses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldgolf.com/golf-architects/bill-baker.html|title=Bill Baker - golf course architect - golf courses built, articles, related information|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Pickens and her twin sister Christine, both British citizens, moved from England to the Bahamas in 1965.<ref name=Pickens>{{cite book |last=Pickens |first= T. Boone|title=The First Billion Is the Hardest: Reflections on a Life of Comebacks and America's Energy Future |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MNn9qzwZD-UC |date=2008|publisher=Crown Publishing Group |ISBN=9780307449818 |pages=185–6}}</ref> At some point she started using the name Madeleine Farris.<ref name=Hovdey>{{cite book | first=Jay| last=Hovdey|title=Cigar: America's Horse|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pMLWWJcSjPkC|year=1999|publisher=Eclipse Press|page=38}}</ref>
Pickens [[Model (person)|modeled]] and worked as a [[flight attendant]] for [[Pan American Airlines]] in her twenties. She moved to [[Marina Del Rey, California]] in 1969 and went into business for herself, providing cabin service crews for [[Business jet|corporate jets]] and special [[Charter airline|charter flights]].<ref name=range1>{{cite web|last=Finley |first = Tom |url=http://www.rangemagazine.com/features/winter-11/wi11-range-mustang.pdf|title=Special Report: MUSTANG Legends and Myths. Faith, Hope and Charity|website=Range Magazine Winter, 2011}}</ref> In 1976, she was featured in an article in [[Black Belt (magazine)|''Black Belt'' magazine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KdQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=%22Madeleine+Farris%22&source=bl&ots=eV9fTilCMf&sig=51t_Iqr0Mox2pdWIBBYqOrKqtIg&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=6&ct=result#PPA44,M1 |title=November 1976 feature article on Madeleine Farris in ''Black Belt'' magazine |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2017-09-11}}</ref> She was married to Dr. Robert Richter,<ref name=range1/> with whom she had a daughter, Dominique, in 1980.<ref name=seals>{{cite web|url=http://www.delmartimes.net/sddmt-golf-and-gala-fundraiser-for-navy-seals-set-for-2014mar14-story.html|title=Golf and gala fundraiser for Navy SEALs set for March 22 at Del Mar Country Club|first=|last=Staff|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref><ref name= range>{{cite web|url=http://www.rangemagazine.com/features/winter-13/range-wi13-mustang_maddy.pdf|website=Range Magazine|title=Mustang Maddy}}</ref>
She met Allen Paulson, the founder of [[Gulfstream Aerospace]] in 1983,<ref name=Hovdey /> and married him in 1988. In 1993 they bought the Del Mar Country Club in [[Rancho Santa Fe, California]], where she drew upon her background to design and build the golf course.<ref name=delmar>{{cite web|url=https://www.delmarcountryclub.com/club/scripts/library/view_document.asp?NS=PUBLIC&DN=HISTORY|title=Del Mar Country Club View Library Document: History|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Upon Paulson's death in 2000, she and his children from his previous marriages disputed over the estate until 2003, at which time she was awarded in the settlement, among other assets, stock in the Country Club. In September 2015, the [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] filed suit against beneficiaries of Paulson's estate, including Pickens, for unpaid estate taxes.<ref name=wm>{{cite web|url=http://www.wealthmanagement.com/estate-planning/who-s-liable-unpaid-estate-taxes|title=Who's Liable for Unpaid Estate Taxes?|date=15 September 2016|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> On September 10, 2018, a judge ruled Pickens was not liable for the taxes.<ref>https://www.law360.com/articles/1081117/calif-court-oks-lien-on-assets-in-gulfstream-founder-s-trust</ref>
In 2005, she married Texas oilman [[T. Boone Pickens]]. Not long after their marriage, the couple traveled to New Orleans to rescue pets stranded during the evacuation from [[Hurricane Katrina]] and flew them to California and Colorado on a chartered cargo jet.<ref name=Pickens/> They divorced early in 2013.<ref>Sonia Smith, [http://www.texasmonthly.com/story/t-boone-and-madeleine-pickens’-super-sad-true-divorce-story "T. Boone and Madeleine Pickens’ Super Sad True Divorce Story"], ''Texas Monthly'', January 21, 2013.</ref>
In 2007, Pickens paid $35 million for a home on the beach in [[Del Mar, California|Del Mar]]; in 2010 she sued the city for ordering her to prune plants that were obstructing her neighbors' view.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-del-mar-settles-billionaire-hedges-2010mar09-story.html|title=Del Mar settles with billionaire over hedges|first=Tanya|last=Mannes|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Pickens has sponsored several events at the Del Mar Country Club benefiting military organizations.<ref name=seals /><ref name=delmar /> In July 2016, Pickens, [[Jenny Craig (entrepreneur)|Jenny Craig]], and [[Doug Manchester]] co-chaired a fundraiser for [[Donald Trump]] at the Del Mar Country Club in Rancho Santa Fe.<ref>{{cite web|author=Joshua Stewart|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/politics/sdut-trump-fundraiser-san-diego-2016jul13-story.html|title=Trump attends Rancho Santa Fe fundraiser|newspaper=San Diego Union-Tribune|date=July 13, 2016}}</ref>
==Equine interests==
Pickens is said to be a lifelong equestrian.<ref name=plutocrat>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SwGdfAVhmSUC|title=Wild Horses of the West|first=Ed|last=de Steiger|publisher=University of Arizona Press|page=200}}</ref> She developed an interest in thoroughbred [[flat racing]] and with Allen Paulson, she owned several race horses, including [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|U.S. Racing Hall of Fame]] inductee [[Cigar (horse)|Cigar]],<ref>Hovdey</ref> which she traded to husband Allen for the filly, [[Eliza (horse)|Eliza]], the 1992 [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]] winner and that year's [[Eclipse Award]] winner as [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Filly]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html|title=Garden Roars This Time for a Four-Footed Hero: Cigar|first=Robin|last=Finn|date=3 November 1996|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> Pickens' other horses included [[Fraise]], who won the 1992 [[Breeders' Cup Turf]];<ref name=nyt>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/03/sports/othersports/03horses.html|title=Former Owner of Racehorses Now Works to Save Them|newspaper=The New York Times|date=1 May 2009|first=Jillian|last=Dunham}}</ref> [[Yokohama (horse)|Yokohama]] winner of the 1997 [[Prix Foy]] at [[Longchamp Racecourse]];{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} and [[Rock Hard Ten]], winner of the 2005 [[Santa Anita Handicap]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equibase.com/profiles/Results.cfm?type=Horse&refno=6143344&registry=T|title=Equibase - Horse Racing - Horse Racing Entries - Horse Racing Results - Past Performances - Mobile - Statistics|first=|last=Equibase.com|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Pickens and Jenny Craig owned [[Rock and Roll (horse)|Rock and Roll]] who won the 1998 [[Pennsylvania Derby]] and ran in the [[Kentucky Derby]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equibase.com/profiles/Results.cfm?type=Horse&refno=4005633&registry=T&rbt=TB|title=Equibase - Horse Racing - Horse Racing Entries - Horse Racing Results - Past Performances - Mobile - Statistics|first=|last=Equibase.com|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Pickens also raced Miss Dominique, named for her daughter.<ref>Hovdey, op. cit. p. 109</ref>
After the settlement of Paulson's estate, Pickens no longer had [[Jockey#Racing colors|colors]] to race,<ref name=range1/> although she was still part owner of Rock Hard Ten and a few broodmares. She announced in June 2005 that, upon her marriage to T. Boone Pickens, her involvement with racing would be reduced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/169842/madeleine-paulson-to-wed-t-boone-pickens-scaling-back-on-horse-business|title=Madeleine Paulson to Wed T. Boone Pickens; Scaling Back on Horse Business|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> At the same time, she took up equine welfare causes when [[Old Friends Equine]] purchased Fraise and multiple Grade One winner [[Ogygian]] from their Japanese owners and she paid the $65,000 to bring them back to retirement at the Old Friends facility in [[Georgetown, Kentucky]].<ref name=nyt /> About a year after their marriage, the couple led the fight to close the last horse [[slaughterhouse]] in the United States.<ref name=range1/> The slaughterhouses were closed due to Congress's prohibiting funds to pay inspectors in the year appropriations bills,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.horsetalk.co.nz/2017/08/27/lawmakers-protections-american-wild-horses/ |title=Lawmakers in bid to restore threatened protections to America's wild horses |publisher=Horsetalk.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2017-09-11}}</ref> but the Pickens worked for a more permanent solution by lobbying Congress to pass the American Horse Slaughter Prevention Act (AHSPA), which passed in the [[United States House of Representatives]],<ref name=bloodhorse>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/37435/t-boone-pickens-madeleine-pickens-to-receive-equine-advocates-award|title=T. Boone Pickens, Madeleine Pickens to Receive Equine Advocates Award|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> but not in the Senate (In 2015, the AHSPA was folded into the proposed Safeguard American Food Exports Act.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.horsecouncil.org/press-release/the-safeguard-american-food-exports-act-of-2015/|title=The Safeguard American Food Exports Act of 2015 - American Horse Council|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref>). In recognition of their efforts, in 2007 Madeleine and Boone Pickens received the Equine Advocates' Safe Home Equine Protection Award.<ref name=bloodhorse />
In the summer of 2008, the [[Bureau of Land Management]] (BLM), was faced with a budget crisis in its free-roaming horse program due to the cost of maintaining 33,000 excess (unadopted) horses captured on public lands in holding facilities. The agency was considering implementing the options that Congress had provided for in amendments to the [[Wild and Free-Roaming Horses and Burros Act of 1971]], to either euthanize or sell the horses "without limitation" to any willing buyer<ref>{{cite web|author=By Malinda OsbornePosted Oct. 15, 2008 |url=https://www.avma.org/News/JAVMANews/Pages/081101e.aspx |title=Wild horses could face euthanasia |publisher=Avma.org |date=2008-11-01 |accessdate=2017-09-11}}</ref> Since "any willing buyer" included those that would send the horses to [[Horse slaughter|slaughter]] in foreign countries,<ref name=abc>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/PersonOfWeek/story?id=6307278&page=1|title=Oil Billionaire's Wife Drafts Horse Rescue Plan|first=A. B. C.|last=News|date=21 November 2008|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Pickens established "The National Wild Horse Foundation," to create a sanctuary for excess horses.<ref name=mm>{{cite web|url=http://mustangmonument.com/about-mustang-monument/madeleine-pickens/|title=Madeleine Pickens - Mustang Monument Eco-Resort|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> On November 21, 2008, Pickens was named Person of the Week by [[ABC News]] due to her announcement that she would adopt and maintain, with private funds, all 33,000 horses at the sanctuary.<ref name=abc /> However, shortly thereafter she stated that the recession forced many of the donors she hoped would help her pay for the venture backed out, and she requested the BLM pay her a yearly stipend of $500 per horse to maintain the horses. The BLM responded that it was not possible to enter into the contract she requested.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/06/AR2009030602211_2.html</ref>
In January, 2010, Pickens hired three helicopters to view and photograph a BLM horse gather, and at one point they flew across the flight path of other helicopters being used to herd animals, leading to the accusation she had interfered with the gather.<ref name=range1/> A year later, a $500,000 float she sponsored for the [[Rose Parade|Tournament of Roses Parade]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-madeleine-pickens-rose-parade-float-message-hits-2011jan03-story.html|title=Madeleine Pickens' Rose Parade message hits home|first=Diane|last=Bell|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> depicted a Native American on a horse watching over several galloping horses. The day before the parade, the National Tribal Horse Coalition issued a news release objecting to the float for using "the symbolism of the North American Indians and horses to promote agendas in direct opposition to the tribes' position."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cowboycountrymagazine.com/2010/12/rose-bowl-parade-controversy/|title=Rose Bowl Parade Controversy - Canadian Cowboy Country Magazine|date=31 December 2010|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref>
Also in 2010, Pickens purchased property in [[Elko County, Nevada|Elko County]] in northeast Nevada; the 14,000 acre Spruce Ranch in the remote [[Goshute Valley]] for $2,570,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elkodaily.com/news/local/horse-sanctuary-in-elko-county-pickens-buys-spruce-ranch/article_c624c450-d378-11df-b3ed-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Horse sanctuary in Elko County? Pickens buys Spruce Ranch|first=MARTIN GRIFFITH Associated Press|last=Writer|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Shortly afterwards. she purchased the Warm Creek Ranch <ref name=mm /> which is located about 25 miles south of [[Wells, Nevada]]<ref name =blm2>{{cite web|url=https://www.blm.gov/nv/st/en/fo/elko_field_office/blm_information/nepa/nenvwh_ecosanctuary/nenvwh_ecosanctuary.html|title=NENVWH EcoSanctuary photos|date=7 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> on [[U.S. Route 93|Highway 93]], adjacent to the northwest boundary of the 508,000 acre BLM [[Spruce Mountain (Nevada)|Spruce Mountain]] grazing allotment. In March 2011, the BLM put out invitations for Pickens and others who wished to provide lands to maintain horses for the BLM in "Eco_Sanctuaries" to submit proposals for evaluation.<ref>{{cite article|last=Harding|first=Adella|title=BLM seeks horse eco-sanctuaries|journal=Elko Daily News| url=http://elkodaily.com/news/local/blm-seeks-horse-eco-sanctuaries/article_cd485900-50ae-11e0-8ce5-001cc4c002e0.html | date=March 17, 2011| accessdate= November 23, 2017}}</ref> ''Saving America's Mustangs'' the formerly named National Wild Horse Foundation to which Pickens had transferred title to the Spruce Ranch, submitted a proposal to maintain horses, that the BLM agreed to evaluate in April 2012.<ref>https://www.blm.gov/or/news/files/PublicPrivateLandEcosancPressRel_v8.pdf</ref> In August 2012, the BLM published the proposal in the Federal Register<ref>https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2012/08/15/2012-20022/notice-of-intent-to-prepare-an-environmental-impact-statement-for-proposed-wild-horse-eco-sanctuary</ref> but in June 2014 the evaluation stalled after scoping found issues that have yet to resolved. Although she has purchased several hundred horses at risk of slaughter and maintains them on the private lands of the ranches,<ref name=agweekly>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Dylan Harris |url=http://www.agupdate.com/theprairiestar/agweekly/news/enquine/wild-horse-eco-sanctuary-up-in-the-air/article_c78db297-9f9f-58d5-b585-14d4f260fc6d.html|title =Wild horse eco-sanctuary up in the air| website=Ag Weekly|accessdate=February 12, 2017}}</ref> in 2014 Saving America's Mustangs leased the Spruce Allotment grazing permit to the ''Spruce Grazing Association'' that instead grazes cows.<ref>http://files.ctctcdn.com/839d98d3101/6b749792-8c4f-4cf2-94fb-2d8a74065a64.pdf</ref> On December 21, 2017, the BLM announced it would be rounding up horses in the area of the Spruce allotment.<ref>https://www.blm.gov/programs/wild-horse-and-burro/herd-management/gathers-and-removals/nevada/2018-Triple-B-Complex-wild-horse-gather</ref> On August 25, 2018, the BLM announced an emergency gather of 300 horses at Boone Spring within the allotment. <ref>https://www.reviewjournal.com/local/local-nevada/lack-of-food-leads-to-wild-horse-roundup-in-eastern-nevada/</ref>
==Mustang Monument Eco-Resort==
Initially the Warm Creek Ranch headquarters was slated to be used as the "base of operations" for the eco-sanctuary.<ref name=blm>{{cite web |url=https://www.blm.gov/style/medialib/blm/nv/field_offices/elko_field_office/information/nepa/eiss/archives/nenvwh_ecosanctuary.Par.21472.File.dat/EcoSanctuaryScopingBrief.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321102508/https://www.blm.gov/style/medialib/blm/nv/field_offices/elko_field_office/information/nepa/eiss/archives/nenvwh_ecosanctuary.Par.21472.File.dat/EcoSanctuaryScopingBrief.pdf |archivedate=2017-03-21 |df= }}</ref> However, on September 11, 2012, Pickens made reference to plans for a luxury resort called the ''Mustang Monument: Wild Horse Eco-Resort''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rtfitchauthor.com/2012/09/12/madeleine-pickens-eco-resort/|title=Madeleine Pickens' Eco-RESORT?|date=12 September 2012|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Pickens began converting the headquarters for the resort,<ref name=range /> and began renovating the old ranchhouse there to become a dining hall and kitchen.<ref name=code /> On April 3, 2013, the Elko County Commission approved a liquor license for venture,<ref>http://www.elkocountynv.net/4_3_4_13.pdf</ref> and Pickens spent a million dollars on "Safari Tents" or Tee Pees for the guests. The eco-resort was open for business in the summer of 2014 and, among other things, offered horseback rides on BLM-administered public lands<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunset.com/travel/wild-horses|title=The fight over America's wild horses|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/8bba616c-ed87-11e3-abf3-00144feabdc0|title=Financial Times|website=Financial Times|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref> and using a road crossing BLM administered lands to the Spruce Ranch to take guests to see the horses kept there.<ref name=agweekly/> Pickens states she was informed by the BLM in December of that year that she would need a permit to use the road and public lands for her commercial ventures and that she filed the application for the permit. Pickens claims that in October 2015 the BLM told her the paperwork had been misplaced,<ref name=open>http://mustangmonument.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Mustang-Monument-Prevented-from-Opening-for-2016-Season-Feb-2016.pdf</ref> and her representative claims that the BLM requested trivial information to process the application.<ref name=losing>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasnow.com/news/i-team-madeleine-pickens-losing-battle-with-the-blm/542942332|title=I-Team: Madeleine Pickens' losing battle with the BLM|first=|last=LAKANA|date=2 September 2016|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Also, Elko County officials determined that the food preparation facilities she planned did not meet the County health and safety codes, and required her to install a commercial kitchen.<ref name=code>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasnow.com/news/i-team-elko-countys-strict-building-codes-raise-questions|title=I-Team: Elko County's strict building codes raise questions|first=|last=LAKANA|date=5 September 2016|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> By February, 2016 the BLM had not finished processing the permit application and the County's safety codes had not yet been met. The County required Pickens to, in case of fire, to put sprinkler systems<ref name=code /> in the lavishly furnished teepees,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mustangmonument.com/luxury-tipis/|title=Glamping Vacation Luxury Camping - Mustang Monument|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> and because the town of Wells had, in 2008, suffered a major earthquake,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/trending/silver-state/8-biggest-earthquakes-nevada-history|title=8 biggest earthquakes in Nevada history|first=STEPHANIE GRIMES|last=REVIEWJOURNAL.COM|date=31 March 2014|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> she was required to modify the walk-in cooler in the kitchen to be earthquake proof.<ref name=code /> Pickens issued a press release on February 10, 2016, stating the resort would not open for 2016,<ref name=open /> but although the Mustang Monument website stated she hoped to open in 2017<ref name=mm3>{{cite web|title=Reservations|website=Mustang Monument Wild Horse eco-resort|url=http://mustangmonument.com/reservations/ |accessdate=February 5, 2017}}</ref> and having spent $25 million on the venture,<ref name=open /> she stated on September 1, 2016, she was "out of it" and would sell the Tee Pees. [[George Knapp (journalist)|George Knapp]], an investigative reporter for a Las Vegas television station, reported that Pickens said that she had made a bad decision and she would not spend more money on the venture.<ref name=code /> The webpage for Mustang Monument announced the facility was closed in 2016 and was not updated since.<ref name=mm3 />
Pickens stated that her problems with acquiring the BLM permit are due to her being "a tall tree" that "catch(es) the wind."<ref name=open /> Pickens' representative suggested the real reasons for Elko County's safety requirements were due to local hostility to a wild horse sanctuary and because Pickens was from California, and Knapp, a [[Coast to Coast AM]] host that had Pickens' representative on as a guest in 2012,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coasttocoastam.com/shows/2012/03/18/ |title=Wild Horses/ UFO Detection - Shows |publisher=Coasttocoastam.com |date=2012-03-18 |accessdate=2017-09-11}}</ref> expanded upon that to imply that they were imposed because Pickens was "rich, blonde, female, and...from California."<ref name=code/> Adding to the conflicts in 2016, a lawsuit against Saving America's Mustangs and the Del Mar Country Club was filed for an alleged racially motivated hostile work environment at the Country Club and Mustang Monument in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elkodaily.com/news/local/pickens-ranch-target-of-discrimination-lawsuit/article_636822f5-bf4f-5f54-b1f4-64b0de729aa0.html|title=Pickens ranch target of discrimination lawsuit|first=ADELLA HARDING Free Press|last=Correspondent|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> As of January 2017, that lawsuit was pending.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elkodaily.com/news/local/pickens-discrimination-lawsuit-is-back-in-court/article_56adeed7-f6a0-5d2c-8623-58c07091eb67.html|title=Pickens discrimination lawsuit is back in court|first=ADELLA HARDING Free Press|last=Correspondent|publisher=|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://mustangmonument.com/about-mustang-monument/saving-americas-mustangs/ Mustang Monument's "Saving America's Mustangs" Webpage]
